human: Representative Mike Johnson wasn’t the first — or second — choice for speaker of the House, but he was the only congressman to successfully secure a majority of votes.

llm: Representative Mike Johnson is the next speaker of the U.S. House.
His election does not bode well for America, especially if you believe in equality and justice for all.

human: What small moments from your life do you think about often?

human: Roni Abuharon, a detective in the southern Israeli city of Ofakim, grabbed his pistol and floppy police hat.

human: Naya Qeshta was born in Rafah on November 11.

human: The last time I went to the Peking Duck House on Mott Street, I drank a lot of good wine.

human: To borrow some terminology from professional wrestling, an art form much beloved by the traders and lawyers of “Billions” (to say nothing of the show’s writers), Mike Prince is a monster heel champion.

He is an effective villain because he has been booked to be unstoppable — all to better set up the moment when he is stopped.
llm: To borrow some of the great one-liners from “Billions” this week (I have to say that I like what the writers are doing with Lara Axelrod), let me just say that the episode was…

human: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain survived a major threat to his leadership on Tuesday, advancing his flagship immigration policy over the objections of hard-right factions in his Conservative Party.

llm: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is trying to convince his Conservative colleagues to back a plan for Britain to send 10,000 troops to Uganda and Rwanda in an effort to end the war there once and for all.
The British have already committed significant resources to the region, but a full-scale invasion of the African continent could be a costly venture.

human: Peter Crombie, an actor who was probably best known for his memorable portrayal of “Crazy” Joe Davola on five episodes of the hit sitcom “Seinfeld,” died on Wednesday in a health care facility in Palm Springs, Calif.

llm: Peter Crombie, an actor who appeared in more than two dozen films and television series, including “The X-Files,” “Seinfeld” and “Twin Peaks,” but was perhaps best known for playing the murderous Mr. Pitt in the classic “Seinfeld” episode “The Susie,” died on Jan. 14 in Los Angeles.
He was 71.

human: Lena Beseiso, a U.S. citizen, described her journey from Gaza to Egypt.
llm: Lena Beseiso, a U.S. citizen, crossed the Rafah border on Saturday into Gaza.
She was accompanied by her two Palestinian children.
Lena’s husband is from Gaza and they live in the West Bank city of Ramallah.
They have been trying to visit Gaza for many years but were unable to do so because of the closure imposed by Israel on Gaza.
The Israeli authorities refused to give them permits to travel via Erez crossing.
They also tried to get permission to cross via Rafah border crossing, but the Egyptians had closed it.

human: On Tuesday, I made the wrenching but necessary decision to resign as Harvard’s president.
For weeks, both I and the institution to which I’ve devoted my professional life have been under attack.
My character and intelligence have been impugned.
My commitment to fighting antisemitism has been questioned.
My inbox has been flooded with invective, including death threats.
I’ve been called the N-word more times than I care to count.
llm: On Tuesday, I wrote about the controversy surrounding Claudine Gay’s appointment as the first woman of color to chair the Faculty of Arts and Sciences (FAS).
This morning, Gay sent me a statement via email.
Here it is in full.

human: The prime minister of Papua New Guinea on Thursday declared a two-week state of emergency in the capital, Port Moresby, and suspended the Pacific island nation’s chief of police after violent protests left the city shellshocked.
llm: The prime minister of Papua New Guinea, Michael Somare, has declared a state of emergency in the capital, Port Moresby, after rioting over the past week left at least 18 people dead and hundreds injured.
The unrest began last Thursday when residents angry about government plans to relocate them from settlements on the edge of the city clashed with police.
Hundreds of youths burned cars and buildings, including several government offices.
Mr. Somare said he would not allow a small minority to disrupt life in the city.
He blamed the violence on the use of marijuana by some young people.
A police spokesman said a number of suspects had been arrested and that the situation was under control.

human: Almost two years have passed since I began trying to draw people’s attention to the widening gap between economic perceptions and economic reality.
At the time the economic picture was mixed, with rapid job growth yet also rising inflation; even given that mixed picture, consumer sentiment seemed abnormally low.
llm: Almost two years ago, I wrote about how the economic crisis had become a “feel-bad economy.”
The unemployment rate was rising sharply and there was little sign that it would stop anytime soon.
The stock market had been cut in half.
The government was bailing out major financial institutions and debating whether to do so for automakers.
And in many parts of the country, housing prices were still falling.

human: You may be partly joking, Mary, but this is probably a minor reason Democrats do a bit better among older voters than people might guess!

human: The video shows a projectile streaking through the darkened skies over Gaza and exploding in the air.

llm: The video shows an Israeli missile striking the Al-Wafa rehabilitation hospital in Shuja'iya, a neighborhood of Gaza City, on July 17.

human: Every spring, trillions of flowers mate with the help of bees and other animals.
They lure the pollinators to their flowers with flashy colors and nectar.
As the animals travel from flower to flower, they take pollen with them, which can fertilize the seeds of other plants.
llm: Every spring, trillions of flowers emerge in a riotous explosion of color and scent.
Their aim: to get pollinated by insects or other animals so that they can reproduce—a process that also helps the plants produce fruits and seeds that feed many different species.
But new research published this week in Science Advances suggests that over time, some flowers may have become less reliant on sex for survival.

human: Update: The mayor of London on Sunday announced that the planned Tube strike had been suspended.
llm: Update: The mayor of London is now pushing for a 24-hour Tube service.

human: Instead of the usual “each week we choose a theme, and bring you three or four stories on that theme” business, this episode of “This American Life” throws all that away and brings you 20 stories — yes, 20 — in 60 minutes.
llm: Instead of the usual one-hour episode, we've got twenty acts playing one song each.

The lineup includes: Paul Simon, Patti Smith, John Fogerty, Jackson Browne, Emmylou Harris, Bonnie Raitt, James Taylor, Taj Mahal, Eric Burdon, the Doobie Brothers, Crosby, Stills & Nash, Stevie Wonder, Carole King, the Eagles, Linda Ronstadt, Billy Joel, Joni Mitchell, and Neil Young.

human: Julia Kate Tiller and Eric Daniel Graves didn’t meet at her older brother’s graduation in 2019, although they both attended (Mr. Graves is Ms. Tiller’s brother’s friend).

human: President Biden told Israel’s leaders on Tuesday that they were losing international support for their war in Gaza, exposing a widening rift with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who rejected out of hand the American vision for a postwar resolution to the conflict.
llm: President Biden told the Israeli people that "The United States will not look away," and vowed to work for a two-state solution.
But he also cautioned Israelis about their future in the Middle East, saying that Israel was losing support among Americans because of its military offensive against Hamas.

human: Joseph Lelyveld, who worked as a reporter and editor at The New York Times for 39 years, the last seven of them as executive editor, died on Jan. 5.

llm: Joseph Lelyveld, who was executive editor of The New York Times from 1994 to 2001, is the author, most recently, of Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India.

human: Here’s a holiday recipe you probably haven’t made.
llm: Here’s a holiday-season puzzle for you: what toy was the subject of a recent headline in the Wall Street Journal that read “The Strangest Toy on Kids’ Holiday Wish Lists”?

llm: With great fanfare, CNN announced last week that it would be holding a debate in New Hampshire just days before the state’s primary.

human: An inmate stabbed Derek Chauvin 22 times last week at a federal prison in Tucson, Ariz., the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Arizona said on Friday in announcing attempted murder charges.
llm: An inmate stabbed a former Minneapolis police officer 22 times at the Hennepin County jail this weekend, federal prosecutors said Monday.

human: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter on Monday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
llm: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy as nearly half the staff considers leaving, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

The nonprofit artificial intelligence research company is losing scientists and engineers because they’re frustrated with its bureaucracy and lack of accountability, said the people, who asked not to be identified discussing internal matters.

llm: For nearly a year, Michael Weiss, a Florida dentist and former law professor, had been under investigation by the FBI for an alleged murder-for-hire plot against another law professor.

llm: WILMINGTON, Del. — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who is running for president in 2020, has picked a new campaign manager: Greg Schultz, the executive director of Mr. Biden’s political action committee.

human: Artem Marchuk needed to escape Ukraine or die.
He didn’t see any other options.
llm: Artem Marchuk needed to get out of Ukraine fast in 2014 when it was invaded by Russia and the government started drafting men into military service.
So he fled to the United States on a tourist visa and requested asylum.

human: “The Core of an Onion,” Mark Kurlansky’s latest single-subject food book, made me think of Thanksgiving.
He devotes an entire chapter to creamed onions, essential at Thanksgiving dinner when I was growing up.
His book has recipes for them dated to 1665 and a reference to the 1941 film “They Died With Their Boots On,” in which the onions play a role alongside Errol Flynn.

Other discussions of onion cookery — as in soup, stuffed, fried, breads, pickled, with eggs, in sandwiches (famously by James Beard) and more, with recipe histories — follow an unraveling of the onion botanically, historically, medicinally, literally, economically and gastronomically around the world.
Despite relevant but overlong digressions on the origins of the Gibson and of the bagel, it’s a lively read.
On the culinary side he might have touched on the Spanish tortilla when discussing eggs and onions; he makes an interesting point about swapping cream for milk when using older recipes.
llm: “The Core of the Onion is a delightful and illuminating book, as witty as it is profound.
It's filled with surprising revelations about food history that will change how you think about some of your favorite dishes.”
—Tom Standage, author of An Edible History of Humanity

human: Grief moves slowly, and war moves quickly.
After Hamas assailants killed at least 1,400 Israelis and took hundreds more hostage, Israel dropped more than 6,000 bombs on Gaza in the first week of a conflict that is ongoing.
So far, more than 5,000 Palestinians are reported dead and many more injured.
There’s no one way to cover this that reconciles all that is happening and all that needs to be felt.
llm: Grief moves slowly, in its own time.
You can't hurry it; you can't force it into some preconceived timetable of stages.
Grief is not a line graph, moving smoothly up and down, but a jagged scribble, with unexpected regressions and unpredicted leaps.
It is not an experience to be gotten over but to be lived through.

human: In New York, where roughly 7.7 million people flowed through the southern half of Manhattan every weekday before the pandemic — almost a quarter of them by motor vehicle — finding a place to park is not exactly easy.
llm: In New York, the problem of parking is an enduring and contentious one.
The city’s most recent transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, has called it “the third rail of transportation policy.”

human: There are two big questions right now about the U.S. economy.
One is why it’s doing so well.
The other is why so many Americans insist that it’s terrible.
llm: There are two ways to think about the Democratic primary contest.
One is that it’s a race between candidates with wildly different views of what America should look like.
The other is that it’s an argument about how to achieve shared goals, such as making health care more affordable and accessible.
From this perspective, Joe Biden is the most progressive candidate in the field.

Overcoats of all sorts: Single-breasted and double-breasted, in shades of camel and pink, some skimming knees and others falling closer to the floor.

human: This week, I called Dr. Izzeldin Abuelaish, a physician from Gaza who now lives in Canada, to check in on him.

Among them, he said, were five babies.
llm: This week, I'm honored to share a guest post by my friend and fellow author, Jo Huddleston.
Welcome, Jo!

human: Nearly 50 years to the day after the Yom Kippur War in 1973, Israel was again taken by surprise by a sudden attack.
llm: Nearly 50 years after the Six-Day War, an unprecedented look at the war's military campaign.

human: Barely a month after winning a landmark phone-hacking lawsuit against a British publisher, Prince Harry on Friday withdrew an unrelated libel suit against the publisher of another tabloid paper, The Mail on Sunday.

human: Robert H. Precht, who for more than a decade produced “The Ed Sullivan Show,” the Sunday night variety extravaganza that for 23 years brought singers, comedians, rock bands, jugglers, animal acts and the Italian mouse puppet Topo Gigio into the living rooms of millions of viewers, died on Nov. 26 at his home in Missoula, Mont.

llm: Robert H. Precht, a producer and director whose television credits included “The Ed Sullivan Show” and the children’s show “Captain Kangaroo,” died on Aug. 12 in Manhattan.

human: The Great Lawn, the 12-acre oval of green space that is one of the most popular gathering places in Central Park, will be closed to the public until April after it was damaged during a concert late last month, the Central Park Conservancy confirmed on Tuesday.
llm: The Great Lawn, a 55-acre oval in Central Park that is home to many concerts and public events, will be closed until April for repairs.

human: Why run?
I ask myself this question as I lace up my shoes, as I confront an approaching hill, as I coax one more lap out of my aching calves.
The obvious answer is that we run to be healthy, to improve our cardiovascular systems and our moods, to become fitter and stronger.
But sometimes it feels like the real reason that I run is to get better at running.
I run so that I can run more.
llm: Why run?
I am running to honor those who are no longer with us and to support those fighting this disease.
My brother, my sister-in-law, and my best friend have all been diagnosed with breast cancer in the past few years.
The Susan G. Komen 3-Day® is an amazing event that provides funding for groundbreaking research and vital services for women, men and families living with breast cancer.
It’s not about how fast you go or how far you go.
It’s about why you go.
Thank you for your support!

human: Another year, another amazing album from Igor Levit.

Like all this pianist’s recording projects, “Fantasia” is daringly yet elegantly programmed: Eight works from across some 200 years, with four meaty masterpieces each set alongside a smaller companion.
llm: Another year, another list of top classical albums.
And as we did last year, here are five records that you can stream right now (if you have a Spotify account).
The music ranges from the baroque period through to modern times and includes some well-known names and others who may be less familiar.

human: The Supreme Court reiterated on Monday what it had said just two months ago: that the Biden administration may continue to regulate “ghost guns” — kits that can be bought online and assembled into untraceable homemade firearms — while appeals move forward.
llm: The Supreme Court declined to hear a challenge to the 1988 Undetectable Firearms Act, which makes it illegal to manufacture firearms that can evade metal detectors.
The ruling leaves in place an Obama-era regulation banning 3D printed “ghost guns” and other weapons that would be undetectable by security checkpoints.

human: Apple resumed sales of its newest smartwatches on Thursday, a day after a federal appeals court temporarily reversed an earlier ban on their import and sale in the United States.
llm: Apple resumed sales of its newest smartwatch models in the U.S., ending a weeklong hiatus caused by a Federal Trade Commission complaint that it was misleading customers with claims about the health-tracking capabilities of its latest wearable device.

human: In September, at Prada’s spring 2024 women’s show, models walked between translucent curtains of pink slime that dripped from the ceiling and pooled on the floor.
The brand referred to them as “fluid interruptions,” a concept that was echoed in the collection’s flowing organza dresses and fringed skirts.
Above all, though, it evoked the secretions of a snail, an animal that has recently been crawling into the realms of design and fashion.
llm: In September, at Paris Fashion Week, snails were everywhere.
They crawled up models’ legs in Saint Laurent’s show, they slid down pants on the runways of Dries Van Noten and Balenciaga.

And as of last week, they are now on the feet of sneaker-wearing teens: Vans has released a collaboration with the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles that features four different pairs of shoes covered in snails.

human: The Supreme Court is considering whether to take up the question of presidential immunity — that is, the idea that a president, by virtue of the unique nature of the office, is entitled to exceedingly broad protections from legal consequences for statements made and actions taken while in office.
If the court takes up that question in a case regarding Donald Trump, it will have profound consequences for both the 2024 election and the bigger question of presidential power.
llm: The Supreme Court's decision in the census case is one of the most important decisions it will make this term, and not just because of the importance of an accurate count.
As Justice Sonia Sotomayor noted during oral argument last month, the Constitution makes clear that Congress is in charge of redistricting.

So if the administration succeeds in rigging the census count — by adding a citizenship question to discourage noncitizens from participating — it could affect how many congressional seats each state gets for the next decade.

human: It’s the latest hot TV genre: a woman in a frigid outpost, bundled in puffy outerwear, trying to uncover truths buried in ice.
llm: It’s the latest installment of “What’s Up With This Stupid Election?”
and I have to tell you, it just gets weirder and weirder.

human: Around noon on Nov. 17, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, logged into a video call from a luxury hotel in Las Vegas.
He was in the city for its inaugural Formula 1 race, which had drawn 315,000 visitors including Rihanna and Kylie Minogue.
llm: Around noon on Monday, March 19th, a small group gathered for lunch in San Francisco.

The guests included some of Silicon Valley’s most prominent investors and technology thinkers: Sam Altman, president of Y Combinator; Jessica Livingston, founding partner at YC; Peter Thiel, founder of PayPal and Palantir; Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn; Greg Brockman, formerly of Facebook; and Elon Musk, founder of Tesla and SpaceX. Also present were top executives from the three companies that had agreed to fund the nonprofit, which was called OpenAI: Altman, Hoffman, and Musk.

human: After a long day at work, I absent-mindedly boarded an express train.
What should’ve been an 18-minute commute home turned into a 50-minute journey from Manhattan to Brooklyn and back.
Sitting on that last train to my apartment, I felt a digital dreariness overcome me.
I’d spent all day responding to emails, Slacks and DMs.
I just wanted to not look at a screen.
I didn’t have a book with me, so I took out my notebook and jotted down everything I saw, heard or smelled: A backpack occupying a seat for a human.
A woman wearing a spiky hat.
Shoelaces, untied.
Shoelaces, tied.
An aggressively yellow ad for something called Mullvad.
“Do Not Lean on Door.”
Snoring.
The person next to me typing out in a text, “Dinner next week?” before quickly deleting it and locking his phone.
llm: After a long hiatus, I have decided to return to writing.
I hope you enjoy this one!

human: The New York Police Department detained 34 demonstrators at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade who were protesting Israel’s killings of civilians in Gaza, the authorities said on Friday.
llm: The New York Times - November 25, 2016

human: Even as Israeli tanks and ground troops continued to battle Hamas militants in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday outlined a postwar vision for the territory, one that he said would not involve the Palestinian Authority in its current form.
llm: Even as Israeli leaders talk about the need to dismantle Hamas, they are divided over how to achieve that goal.
The prime minister has repeatedly said that Israel’s main aim is to restore quiet along its border with Gaza.
He said on Monday that he would be willing to agree to a cease-fire even before reaching his military goals, but he has not specified what those goals might be.

human: House Republicans on Friday demanded that Hunter Biden, the president’s son, sit for a closed-door deposition in their impeachment inquiry into his father, rejecting his request to testify only in public and suggesting he could face punishment if he did not agree to their terms.
llm: House Republicans on Wednesday demanded that the House Intelligence Committee immediately depose Hunter Biden and the anonymous whistleblower whose complaint sparked the impeachment inquiry, saying public hearings should not begin until their testimony is secured.

human: Several months ago, as a federal judge worked through a docket of smuggling cases in the bustling border city of Laredo, Texas, three people were escorted into the courtroom.
llm: Several months ago, I wrote about a new front in the war on terrorism: the detention of thousands of Muslim men in camps for interrogation.
These are not American citizens, but foreigners who have been arrested by Uzbekistan, Egypt and other governments at the request of the United States.
The Bush administration has come under fire from human rights groups, which say many detainees have been abused.

human: Inflation eased in October and price increases showed encouraging signs of slowing under the surface, according to fresh data released on Tuesday.

llm: Inflation eased in January, according to a new government report that could give the Federal Reserve some breathing room as it tries to steer the economy toward faster growth without spurring too much inflation.

human: On Oct. 25, Professor Nurit Peled-Elhanan, a lecturer at a college in Jerusalem, participated in a discussion in a faculty WhatsApp group about the horrific events of Oct. 7.

In response to another lecturer’s message, she wrote that “the massacre,” referring to the actions of Hamas, reminded her of something the French philosopher and playwright Jean-Paul Sartre once wrote about race relations, adding a paraphrased quote: “‘After so many years that the neck of the occupied has been suffocating under your iron foot and suddenly was given a chance to raise his eyes, what kind of gaze did you expect you would see there?’
We saw this gaze,” Ms. Peled-Elhanan wrote to her colleagues.
llm: On Oct. 25, 1967, the United Nations Security Council unanimously passed Resolution 242, which became the framework for future Israeli-Arab peace negotiations.
The resolution called on Israel to withdraw from territories it captured in the Six Day War in exchange for normalized relations with its Arab neighbors.
But Israel did not fully comply with the resolution’s terms and has continued to occupy the West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem more than five decades later.
This week, as the UN commemorates the anniversary of Resolution 242, we speak to Tariq Ali about his recent piece “Israel: No Peace Without Accountability.”
He argues that Israel will never have peace without accountability for its crimes against Palestini

human: The Republican chairman of the bipartisan House Ethics Committee introduced a resolution on Friday to expel Representative George Santos of New York from Congress, citing the committee’s damning new report documenting violations of House rules and evidence of pervasive campaign fraud.
llm: The Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee is demanding that President Barack Obama disclose details about U.S. support for Syria’s armed opposition, The Cable has learned.

human: Heavy rain and powerful winds stretched up the East Coast, flooding streets and buildings.

llm: Heavy rain and severe thunderstorms moved through the Mid-Atlantic states Friday night, causing flash flooding in some areas.

human: The Biden administration said on Monday that it is looking into reports by Amnesty International and The Washington Post that Israel used white phosphorus supplied by the United States in violation of international law.

human: Can magic illuminate a life that was far from magical?

human: Walking through New York City — America’s great harborer of people, culture and activity — can feel like strolling the world’s largest outdoor mall.

It’s difficult to imagine a product one can’t buy in Manhattan, let alone the boroughs.
llm: Walking through New York City, it is not uncommon to see people on the street with their heads down staring into a phone.
They may be texting or surfing the Internet, but they are more likely looking at an app for a store they will never visit.

human: As Israeli troops moved toward the border with Gaza before a possible ground invasion to dismantle Hamas, a U.N. official warned of a humanitarian “disaster” in the blockaded territory.

human: When Michael Stipe was little, his parents called him Mr. Mouse.
He was a scurrier.
As soon as he could stand, he ran, and when he ran, he ran until he face-planted.

His mother would deposit him in a baby walker, but if Stipe scrambled as fast as he could and hit the threshold of a doorway with a running start, he could topple the walker and eject himself onto the floor.
Then he’d spring to his feet and run away.
llm: When Michael Stipe and R.E.M. announced their breakup in 2011, it was the end of an era.
The Athens, Georgia, band had become one of the most influential in rock history, with songs like “Losing My Religion,” “Everybody Hurts” and “Man on the Moon.”
Stipe’s haunting voice and cryptic lyrics were at the heart of every R.E.M. song, but when the band split up, he left music behind entirely.
In a new interview with Pitchfork, Stipe says that he’s now thinking about what his next act will be — though it might not be as a singer-songwriter.

human: In the 1970s and ’80s, when Rainer Judd was growing up at 101 Spring Street in New York’s SoHo with her father, the artist Donald Judd, she’d sit in the building’s open windows, “because no one told me not to,” she said, and because back then, SoHo was a “creaky, dirty, lovely place.”
In 1971, her father wrote that one day, the neighborhood might be invaded by “tourist shops and restaurants, bad art and high rents.”

And while this premonition has largely come to pass, his home, a cast-iron former textile factory where his family — which also included his wife, the dancer Julie Finch, and his son, Flavin — lived according to Judd’s influential ideas about art and architecture, is almost entirely unchanged.
llm: In the 1970s, when Marfa was a dusty railroad town in West Texas, the artist Donald Judd set about transforming it into a haven for artists.
He bought up land and buildings, including a two-story clapboard house built in the late 1800s, which he turned into his home and studio.
It is now one of five National Historic Landmarks in this tiny town of less than 2,000 people.

human: One by one, the inmates filed into a chapel at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y. — past a line of security officers, past a sign reading, “Open wide the door to Christ.”
Under stained-glass windows, they formed a circle, introducing themselves to a crowd of visitors as composers, rappers, painters and poets.
Then they began to sing.
llm: One by one, the men stepped up on stage and faced their audience.
Some had been incarcerated for years; some were awaiting trial.
They wore green prison uniforms or orange jumpsuits.
A few were handcuffed.
One was bound in a wheelchair.
Their ages ranged from 18 to 56.
All of them were convicted murderers.

human: I first heard the band Sleater-Kinney when I was a teenager, and it’s not an exaggeration to say it changed my life.

The early 2000s were a particularly macho time in rock music — all wounded emo boys and nü-metal aggressors — and even in the late ’90s it was difficult to find female musicians lauded for how well they played their instruments rather than the way they looked.
Then I happened upon a live recording of Sleater-Kinney playing its 1997 song “Words and Guitar,” and it blew my hair back like I’d entered a wind tunnel.
llm: I first heard Sleater-Kinney in 2005, when I was 14.
A friend of mine played me the song “Was It a Lie?” from their album The Woods and I was immediately hooked.
I listened to that song over and over, but when I tried listening to other songs by them, nothing compared.
So I didn’t think much more about it until five years later, when my friend gave me her copy of Dig Me Out for my birthday.
I put the CD on in my car stereo and pressed play.

human: Three people, including a girl, were killed and three others were missing after a landslide struck homes in southeast Alaska this week, the authorities said.

human: There are many reasons to be horrified about recent events in the Middle East, and the prospect that attacks on shipping might undermine progress against inflation is way, way down the list.

But how big a deal is it?
llm: There are many things in our lives that we take for granted.
For instance, I grew up thinking that a glass of water was something that was always available to me whenever I needed it.
It never occurred to me that there were places where people had to walk miles and miles just to get some water for themselves or their families.
And yet, that is exactly what happens every single day.
In fact, according to UNICEF, every 20 seconds a child dies from a water-related disease.
That is why I have decided to support charity:water.

human: Shining out from the Instagram slag heap, amid the endless A.I. selfies and reaction reels, is an account so quiet in presence and noble in intention that it is sometimes hard to believe it exists.

llm: Shining out from the darkness, Madonna's voice is all that can be heard as the music slowly builds.
She sings of a lover who abused her, and she knows he'll come back for more.
The song builds until it explodes in a crescendo of emotions.
It's an amazing way to start a great album.

human: Punctuating a year of major gains for organized labor, Microsoft has announced that it will stay neutral if any group of U.S.-based workers seeks to unionize.
llm: Punctuating a year of increasingly aggressive anti-union activity, Microsoft has filed suit against the United Auto Workers (UAW) union for allegedly defaming the company.

human: Across the U.S., roughly 6 million adults 65 and over have Alzheimer’s disease.
Almost two thirds of them are women — a discrepancy that researchers have long attributed to genetics and women’s longer life spans, among other reasons.
But there is growing consensus that menopause may also be an important risk factor for the development of dementia later in life.
llm: Across the U.S., women are taking hormone replacement therapy to ease the symptoms of menopause, such as hot flashes and night sweats.
But some researchers believe that HRT may also help with memory and mood problems caused by menopause.

human: Sometimes in this job I have a kernel of a column idea that doesn’t pan out.
But other times I begin looking into a topic and find a problem so massive that I can’t believe I’ve ever written about anything else.
This latter experience happened as I looked into the growing bureaucratization of American life.
It’s not only that growing bureaucracies cost a lot of money; they also enervate American society.
They redistribute power from workers to rule makers, and in so doing sap initiative, discretion, creativity and drive.
llm: Sometimes in this life we find ourselves at the end of our rope.
Maybe it’s because of something we did, or maybe it’s due to something beyond our control.
Either way, it can be difficult to see the light at the end of the tunnel.

And while I wish I had all the answers to help you with your troubles, what I do know is that no matter how hard things get, God has promised us that He will never leave us nor forsake us (Hebrews 13:5).

human: Dave Chappelle waded briefly into the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week, drawing cheers from some audience members and causing others to walk out as he decried the humanitarian crisis unfolding at the Gaza Strip, according to news reports and a spokeswoman for the comedian.

human: Ukraine scored a major success on Tuesday when it struck a Russian warship at port in Crimea, one of the most significant attacks against Moscow’s Black Sea Fleet in months.

llm: Ukraine scored a rare victory against Russia over the weekend.

human: My mother and I disagree on a lot, but we often put our disagreements aside to enjoy a healthier relationship, even if it’s on a surface level.
She has been anti-abortion my entire life.
We now live on opposite sides of the country and see each other maybe twice a year.
When she visits, she often speaks of abortion as murder; her tone is visceral.
She is very aware of my pro-choice beliefs, but she does not know that I have had two abortions (neither of which I regret).
I am in my 30s, and each passing year my desire to be a mother decreases exponentially.
Recently, she has begun to complain about her lack of grandchildren.
I have chosen not to tell her about my abortions, because this information might be grief-inducing for her.
But as she continues to push her ideologies on me, I feel more and more compelled to share my life experiences and choices.
What do I owe her?— Name Withheld
llm: My mother and I have always been close, but we don't see eye to eye on everything, especially when it comes to politics.
She's a Christian conservative who believes in small government, low taxes, and that abortion is morally wrong.
I am none of those things.
My mom doesn't know this about me, though: When I was in college, I had two abortions.

human: “Inspector Sun,” a computer-animated family film released in Spain last year and now arriving in an English-language dubbed version, is very clearly a product of the director Julio Soto Gurpide and the screenwriter Rocco Pucillo’s deep affection for motion picture history.
The movie draws on a range of classics, from silent adventure serials to screwball mysteries like “The Thin Man” to the swashbuckling epics of Douglas Fairbanks and Errol Flynn.
llm: “Inspector Sun,” a 2019 film by Liang Heng, is a remake of the 1958 classic “The Crimson-Cloaked Detective” (Hong yin xiong), which was directed by and starred Taiwanese martial arts superstar Huo Feng.
The film has been hailed as an innovative work for its use of a single shot that lasts the entire duration of the movie.

Although the idea of using one continuous camera movement to tell a story is not new, it is still quite rare in Chinese cinema, and Liang deserves credit for making this technique central to his film.

human: Growing up in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, the Opinion editorial assistant Adrian J. Rivera was no stranger to processed food.
As a child, he relished a good Big Mac, a box of chicken nuggets and a cold, refreshing Sprite.
But after moving to the East Coast for college, Rivera’s socioeconomic circles began shifting, as well as his worldview around food.
In this audio essay, he reflects on his relationship with processed food, class and what it’s like to go home with a new set of tastes.
llm: Growing up in a military family, I moved around a lot when I was young, but no matter where I went, I always had one constant: McDonald's chicken nuggets.
When I was upset, I turned to them for comfort; they were my go-to food when I needed some solace from the world.
But as I got older, I started to realize that maybe it wasn’t healthy to turn to something so processed and unhealthy as my main source of comfort, and I decided to stop eating them altogether.
For years, I stuck with this decision, only indulging once in a while.
But last week, after my grandfather passed away, I found myself turning back to those delicious fried treats.

human: A couple of weeks ago, a young crowd in Shanghai came out in force to celebrate Halloween.
The street where I live filled with revelers dressed in a range of elaborate costumes — as the white-clad enforcers of China’s Covid lockdowns, as Chinese courtesans or simply as a watermelon.
Halloween allows us to dress up as something that we can’t otherwise be.

It’s a strong impulse right now in China, which remains stuck in a postpandemic malaise marked by job shortages, a trend of disillusioned 20-somethings dropping out of the work force and society and a general yearning for a different way to be.
llm: A couple of days ago, I wrote about my concern that a "generation gap" was developing between Washington and Beijing.
In the past, China has been led by older men.
The last generation of leaders in their 70s and 80s is being replaced by a new generation of men in their late 50s and early 60s.
It's only natural that the Chinese leadership would want to have a say in how they see their country's future playing out.
Yet, the U.S. seems to be stuck in its own time warp, with President Obama (51), Secretary of State Hillary Clinton (62) and Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner (49) still leading the charge.
While it'

human: In the era of modern consumer confidence data, there has never been an economy quite like this recent one — with prices rising so high and unemployment staying so low.

human: Ever since I was a little girl I’d dreamed of going to Darjeeling.
My imagination was captivated by this town nestled in the foothills of the Himalayas in the Indian state of West Bengal.

Surrounded by lush, terraced tea gardens that extend across rolling hills, with the majestic snow-capped mountains behind them, Darjeeling is one of India’s most stunning hill stations, known as the Queen of the Mountains.
llm: Ever since I visited this place in 2015 it had been on my list to return.
The hotel is one of those wonderful places that has an interesting history which makes you wonder about the characters who lived there.
Built in 1931 by the British tea planter Frank Lumbard Smith, who was also a member of the Darjeeling Planters Club, it was used as a summer retreat for himself, his wife and their five children.
It is said that he built the property so he could have a view over Darjeeling to the plains below.
He would sit in the large bay window of the first floor library and watch the sun rise over the plains and set behind the mountains.
In 1967 the property was sold to Mr N.K

human: On May 20, 1964, on a hilltop in New Jersey, an unlikely little structure called the Holmdel Horn revealed telltale signs of the Big Bang, and the birth of the universe we live in.
The Horn has been much in the news this fall, as it survived a threat of demolition.
llm: On May 20, 1945, Jackson Pollock was arrested for drunk driving in New York City.
He was on his way to a party at Peggy Guggenheim’s home when he was pulled over.
Guggenheim bailed him out, and they married that August.
The two had been seeing each other since January, but this incident was the first time she saw Pollock as “a desperate man.”
It was the beginning of a turbulent relationship, which would end with their separation just four years later.

human: “Everything needed for the front,” Russia’s finance minister declared, echoing a Soviet slogan from World War II as he talked about the government’s latest spending plans.

human: She flirted with Brando and even Prince Charles.

llm: She flirted with a man who was not her husband, and she made a scene.
She did it in front of the world.
She didn't care what anybody thought.
And she had great legs.
I loved that about Ava Gardner.
She wasn't afraid to take chances, to live life on her own terms.
That's why I admire her so much.
In my mind, she'll always be one of the all-time greats.

human: A few blocks from where the Cronut was born, a new pastry mash-up by a French chef is making its debut.

Gregory Doyen developed a cakelike confection inspired by brownies and cookies that’s round, about three inches in diameter, fairly dense and with a central opening where a ganache or fruit filling goes.
Mr. Doyen is calling it MOD, for multilayered original dessert.
It’s offered as a single serving ($7.50 each) and in fours ($29), and can be shared and personalized.
In a show of extreme confidence, it’s the only product sold in the bright white shop of the same name he owns with Edward Geyman, his business partner.

A native of the Burgundy region in France who studied pastry-making and has been a pastry consultant in many countries around the globe, Mr. Doyen, 38, arrived in the United States a year ago and began working on this project.
“I didn’t just want to reproduce French pastry,” he said.
The flavor and filling combinations are endless.

For now he has eight colorful examples, including peanut butter and jelly, matcha with white chocolate, walnut with dark chocolate, red velvet with dark chocolate and raspberry, and pecan caramel with milk chocolate chips and sea salt.
He has a featured flavor of the month, which for now is s’mores with a marshmallow topping that he torches before serving.
He said he’s working on a mini size.
llm: A few blocks from the newest Dominique Ansel Bakery in Los Angeles sits another bakery where customers line up outside to wait for the doors to open at 8am.
This is not just any bakery though - it's home of the MOD, a cookie-brownie-cake hybrid that has quickly become one of LA's hottest treats.
The man behind this treat is Shafer Patel, who opened his first shop in 2014 and has since expanded to three other locations across the city.

human: It will be a long time before any of us understand what happened after Oct. 7, but it seems important first to recognize how news of everything comes to us today.

Newspaper headlines aren’t fixed — they change over the course of a day; social media presents tragedies in fragmented shards, which are then contested and rejected and reaffirmed; television news, especially on foreign affairs, remains too hyper and flashy to take seriously.
Every single one of us had our own individualized experience of that day and the days after it.
No one can confidently say who knew what when.
llm: It will be interesting to see how this generation, who have grown up with war as a constant backdrop to their lives, are going to change our culture.
We can only hope that they will do so for the better.

human: Trader Joe’s, West Hollywood.
“Your total is $20.69,” announces the cashier at my register.
Seconds later, the cashier at the next register over says to a male customer, “Your total is $20.69.”
Wait, what?
The staff whoops.
Someone says, “No way!”
He and I grin sloppily in the sudden spotlight, paired so arbitrarily by groceries.
Bystander: “It’s a rom-com opening, baby!”
The other $20.69 meets my eyes, testing gently for truth in that idea.
For a moment, I entertain another universe — one where I’m not gay — and smile wide.
Then I say, “Good night.”
— Zoe Marie Bel
llm: Trader Joe’s, West Village, New York City.

human: For this landmark biography, Tick, a music historian, leans on a rich trove of archival research — in particular, articles from recently digitized Black newspapers — as well as new material from Fitzgerald’s family, including a scrapbook the jazz legend kept when she was 18.
llm: For this landmark book, the first of its kind, historian William F. Quigley has assembled an impressive array of scholars to examine key issues and events from the past 50 years, including: The impact of World War II on the growth of the state; The role of the courts in promoting social justice; The emergence of a new political economy; Changes in social policy; The politics of identity; And the struggle for cultural independence.

human: “It is up to us to write our own history,” declares the organizer of the desperate project at the heart of Lauren Grodstein’s latest novel, WE MUST NOT THINK OF OURSELVES (Algonquin, 304 pp., $34).
He’s speaking on a bleak afternoonomg in one of the bleakest places in Poland, the Warsaw ghetto in December 1940.

Those he will secretly assemble in the upstairs room of a library are intent on preserving the biographies of at least some of the hundreds of thousands of Jews imprisoned by the Nazis in three square kilometers of the city.
llm: “It is up to each of us,” he writes in the book’s preface, “to resist the pressures of groupthink and to maintain our own standards of conduct.
There are times when we all have to take a stand against the pressures of a group that may be doing something wrong.”

human: The final game of the playoff series between the Houston Astros and the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday lasted only two hours and 38 minutes.
It was a crisply played game — which the Astros won, 3-2 — that highlighted Major League Baseball’s biggest accomplishment this season.
Thanks to a 15-second clock that prevents players from dawdling between pitches, the average game lasted just two hours and 40 minutes this season, down a remarkable 24 minutes from last season.
llm: The final game of the 1964 season for the Yankees would be a 2-0 loss to the Orioles, who had already clinched their first pennant in eight years.
It was a day of strikeouts for New York: Mickey Mantle struck out four times, and Roger Maris twice.
Baltimore’s Jim Palmer pitched his first major league shutout at age 19; he was to win 268 more before retiring with 3,759 career strikeouts.
The Yankees were outscored by the O’s 30-3 during the three-game series in Baltimore.

human: Last week, I asked you to submit a song that feels like fall.

human: During the difficult months of 2020, a writer friend and I decided to read Willa Cather’s fiction together.
What a good antidote to despair that was.
Much of it was rereading, but I’d missed some stories and novels, and I’d never read them sequentially or with a clear sense of Cather’s life.
That spring I also delved into several of the biographies, which taught me something about how such books can vary.
llm: During the difficult first years of her writing career in New York, Cather felt that she was always the newcomer.
She worked hard to fit in and, as a result, had few close friends.
One of them was the writer Floyd Dell, who wrote about their relationship: “The bond between us was our love of the prairie landscape…”
Cather is said to have loved him back, but not romantically; he was too much like a brother for her to be able to think of him in any other way.

human: Jeff Landry, the Louisiana attorney general and a hard-line conservative, trounced a crowded field of candidates on Saturday to become the state’s next governor, cementing Republican control of Louisiana after eight years of divided government.
llm: Jeff Landry, the Tea Party-backed candidate, was elected governor of Louisiana on Saturday in one of the most conservative races in recent memory.
Mr. Landry defeated his Democratic opponent, John Bel Edwards, by more than 5 percentage points in a race that focused almost exclusively on social issues.

human: You didn’t have to be a financial wizard to get a safe return of more than 7 percent on your money for decades to come.

human: Pee-wee Herman’s toys, Robert Gottlieb’s plastic handbags and other unexpected treasures.

human: After winning major gains in wages and benefits from two of the three Detroit automakers, the United Automobile Workers union is looking beyond the Motor City to car companies operating nonunion factories across the South.

human: On Christmas Eve in 2013, Elisa Stead, an American living abroad in Iceland, was ready to celebrate the holiday with her fiancé and his family.
But when she tore open the wrapping on his gift for her, she was disheartened to discover what lay inside: a car-window scraper.
Sure, she lived in a frosty place, but she didn’t own a car.
Receiving such a thoughtless gift made for an unhappy holiday, and the relationship ended within the year.
llm: On Christmas Eve, a young woman named Sarah is out on her way home after shopping in the city.
She's tired and cold, and when she gets back to the house, she notices that someone has left their dog outside without any food or water.
She decides to help the poor dog by leaving him some treats and a blanket.
On Christmas morning, Sarah discovers that the dog who was so grateful for her kindness was actually the pet of Santa Claus himself!
And he rewards her with a special gift.

human: Is there something you have read, watched, listened to, eaten, visited, played or otherwise experienced this year that you think is so bad that you want to discourage others from experiencing it?

human: By Canadian standards, the 10.4 billion Canadian dollar military purchase announced this week moved at light speed, possibly within as little as nine months.
llm: By Canadian standards, the military is a very small part of our economy.

We need to get value for money when we do spend it.
The F-35 is the only option that meets all of our requirements and doesn't cost us more than the alternatives.

human: Less than 24 hours after condemning terrorism in the Middle East in one of the most powerful speeches of his tenure on Tuesday, President Biden was back before television cameras for another statement.
llm: Less than 24 hours after a suicide bomber killed more than 30 people in Turkey, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was back on his home turf in Wilmington, Del., taking the microphone to roaring applause at a Democratic fund-raiser.

human: My wife became pregnant soon after we met, when our relationship was “fluid” and non-monogamous.
We agreed to raise the child together and, at my urging, to have an open relationship.
However, our relationship since has been monogamous.
My wife was injured during the birth of our second child and now finds sex painful and avoids it.
(We had a terrific sex life before the injury.)
When I broached the topic of having other partners and reminded her of our agreement to have an open relationship, she became irritated and said that having kids changed things.
Subsequent discussions resulted in a stalemate.
llm: My wife became increasingly uncomfortable with the idea of sex outside our relationship.
We had been together for 10 years, married for seven, and she agreed to an open marriage.
But a few months ago, she reneged on that agreement and said it made her uncomfortable.
We have a child together.
She says she wants to be monogamous.
Is this fair?
I feel as though I’m being lied to or cheated.
Is there something I can do about it?
—Open Marriage Not So Open

human: The ruins of Mitla sit about 30 miles from Oaxaca in the mountains of southern Mexico, built on a high valley floor as a gateway between the world of the living and the dead.
The site was established in roughly A.D. 200  as a fortified village, and then as a burial ground by the Zapotecs, the so-called Cloud People, who settled in the region around 1500 B.C.
llm: The ruins of Mitla, Oaxaca, Mexico, are an archaeological site and one of the most important Zapotec cities.
The tombs discovered here include some of the oldest in Mesoamerica and have yielded rich troves of artifacts, including many that feature the symbol of a cross within a circle:

human: For the two days after a gunman killed 18 people and injured 13 in Lewiston, Maine, Patrick Hynes and other residents in the area sat in their own homes, under a shelter-in-place order, facing their grief, their rage, in isolation.

human: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes in towns near the Gaza Strip, called into television stations as Palestinian gunmen crossed the border into Israel and invaded their communities on Saturday morning.

llm: Israeli citizens, barricaded in bomb shelters, were terrified.

human: “Put on your masks!”
llm: “Put on your seat belt.”
“Don’t smoke.”
“Wash your hands after going to the bathroom.”
We are familiar with these health messages and likely follow them.
But what if you were told that you could not send your child to school without proof of immunization, or that your favorite food was contaminated?
What if you were ordered to stay at home because you were sick?
These types of public health actions have triggered debate and protests from citizens who feel their rights have been violated.
In this lecture we will explore examples of public health policies and practices that are viewed as an over-reach of government authority.

human: Fuel shortages in the Gaza Strip have grown so dire that the U.N. agency that has helped feed, school and shelter Palestinians there for decades said Wednesday that it might have to start shutting down operations.

human: The Safdie brothers, the filmmaking duo behind “Uncut Gems” (2019) and “Good Time” (2017), are splitting up.

human: “It all began with writing,” goes the first line of Adam Thirlwell’s latest novel, in which a young socialite named Celine is slandered in pornographic, anonymously authored pamphlets circulating in prerevolutionary Paris.

This could have gone without saying, but Thirlwell can’t help himself.

human: Q: I live in a co-op apartment on the Upper West Side.

The chicken was fried in lard until it was golden brown and crispy on the outside but still juicy on the inside.

llm: For many years, I was a professional fashion stylist.

llm: When Mayor Mike Bloomberg was looking for ways to close the New York City budget deficit in 2003, he decided to take a page out of Henry George's book.

human: Jasmine, one of two protagonists in Jean Kwok’s intriguing fourth novel, “The Leftover Woman,” reveals little to the reader at first.

As Jasmine trudges from one job interview to the next, searching for work that will help pay off the “snakeheads” who helped her emigrate from China, she remains as invisible to readers as she is to her pursuers.
llm: Jasmine, one of the two main characters in this novel, is a 17-year old girl from Chicago who has moved to Texas with her father after her mother dies.

human: Kali Uchis basks in pleasure on her fourth studio album, “Orquídeas.”

llm: Kali Uchis basks in her own light on “Orquídeas,” the second single from her forthcoming debut album, Isolation.

human: Born in Mulhouse, France, in 1907, Jean Schlumberger was constantly sketching as a child.
He dreamed of becoming an artist one day, but his parents, who hoped he’d take over the family textile business, sent him to Berlin to practice banking instead.

In his early 20s, he defiantly moved to Paris and opened a jewelry workshop on Rue La Boétie, where he handcrafted delicate floral brooches out of Meissen porcelain, antique cameos and decorative Victorian objects he found at the Marché aux Puces.
His fantastical creations soon captured the attention of the fashion world.
After spotting Princess Marina of Greece and Denmark in a pair of his earrings in 1937, the Italian couturier Elsa Schiaparelli commissioned him to design buttons shaped like fruits and insects.
llm: Born in Mulhouse, France in 1965, Pierre Hardy has been a creative force in the fashion world for over three decades.
He began his career as an assistant to the legendary designer Thierry Mugler before becoming first a footwear and then a ready-to-wear designer at Hermès.
In 1990 he launched his own line of luxury women’s shoes, which was followed by a men’s shoe collection in 2013 and an accessories line in 2017.

human: Caboodle was a sweet but average cat.
Not especially beautiful, intelligent, affectionate or agile, she lived a long, happy, uneventful life.
When she died in September 1999, my husband and I buried her under a rose bush in our backyard.
That October, the month of my 50th birthday and long after the last rose had faded, a single bloom emerged.
For about 10 years after Caboodle’s death, a single rose would bloom in mid-October.
Pretty extraordinary, for an average cat.
— Judith Karp

degrees
Fahrenheit (which is -34.4 Celsius).

human: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies.

Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire.
She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.
llm: Fifty years ago, Erica Jong published “Fear of Flying,” which would become a best seller and, for better or worse, a feminist manifesto.
In honor of the anniversary, we asked writers what the book meant to them, then and now.

human: Amid terrible events abroad and the takeover of the Republican Party by agents of chaos, the U.S. economy has been delivering lots of good news.
All indications are that real G.D.P. is still growing fast; we’re adding jobs at an extraordinary pace, even as inflation continues to fall.
llm: Amid terrible events in Japan, it is important to remember that there are other things going on in the world.
And one of those things, which I have been thinking about a lot lately, is how to deal with our long-term budget problem.

human: Follow our latest updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
llm: Follow our latest coverage of the conflict in Gaza.

human: June Jackson Christmas, a psychiatrist who broke barriers as a Black woman by heading New York City’s Department of Mental Health and Retardation Services under three mayors, died on Sunday in the Bronx.
She was 99.
llm: June Jackson Christmas, the first African-American woman to be a board-certified psychiatrist in New York State, died on June 18 in Manhattan.
She was 99.

human: At the risk of evoking unpleasant memories of high-school English, can we please discuss the word allegory?
It refers to a story or a painting that comes with a moral or a lesson, perhaps a social or political one.

And, in an era when figurative art has returned to prominence, the New York galleries are filled with a profusion of both allegorical paintings and their very opposite — which is to say, paintings that reject third-person narration in favor of first-person self-exposure.
I caught two shows last week — Dana Schutz’s and Tracey Emin’s — that represent the two extremes.
llm: At the risk of sounding like a total dick, I think you are reading too much into this.
I don't see it as a serious comment on the art world, but rather an amusing observation on how silly we all look when we try to be something we aren't.
It's not about being "cool", it's about trying to impress others by pretending to have more knowledge than you actually do.

human: Last week, I wrote about the benefits of small rituals, those everyday acts, repeated regularly in a specific way, that add richness and meaning to our lives.
llm: Last week, I asked readers to share their offbeat Halloween rituals.
Below are some of my favorite responses.
They include a tradition where children dress up as saints, and another in which people carve pumpkins using only knives, spoons and forks.

human: The question of how Britain will respond to President Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act, the $369 billion landmark legislation offering deep subsidies for green investment, has followed Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s finance minister, for most of the past year.
llm: The question of whether or not the United States should provide subsidies for green technology has been a hot-button issue as of late, especially since President Obama's election in 2008.

While some are opposed to the idea of government-funded grants for green companies (as they feel it amounts to picking winners and losers), others argue that government investment is necessary if we hope to compete with countries like China who already have their own green tech initiatives in place.

human: Gavin Newsom has a scant history of tough debates over his two decades as governor and lieutenant governor of California and mayor of San Francisco.
llm: Gavin Newsom has a message for people who watch Fox News.

The Democratic governor of California — a state President Donald Trump has attacked as “out of control” — is launching an ad campaign in Los Angeles and the San Francisco Bay Area, with spots set to run on Fox’s “The Ingraham Angle,” “Tucker Carlson Tonight,” and other shows.
The 30-second spot will air at least four times per day through Thursday.

human: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said Sunday that criminal proceedings had been initiated over an episode in which Russian missiles struck a group of Ukrainian soldiers at an award ceremony in the south of the country, killing some and leaving others wounded.
llm: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said the killing of four soldiers at a military parade in Kharkiv was an “act of terrorism,” and he vowed to find those responsible.

human: Humans are a remarkably ambitious species.
We came to the edge of lands we could safely chart and built ships that would carry us to the unknown.
When travel by water and land no longer suited us, we took to the skies.
After journeying among the clouds could not sate our spirit, we turned our hearts to the stars.
llm: Humans are a part of nature, but we don't always behave like it.
We have an innate tendency to seek dominion over the natural world and try to control it for our own benefit.
This is a serious problem in today's world, as our numbers grow exponentially and our technological abilities increase at a staggering rate.
In addition to the massive amounts of energy we expend every day, we also produce huge quantities of waste.
Our activities often have unintended consequences, and we can be very slow to react to these changes, because they tend to happen on a scale that we cannot easily perceive.

human: It was the depths of the Cold War in the 1960s, and Caracas was on edge.
llm: It was the first time since 2013 that Venezuela had renewed its claim.
The government in Caracas also has long disputed Guyana’s border with Suriname, a former Dutch colony on the northern coast of South America.

human: Nasreen Parveen decided to run for her life at the same moment she decided not to end it.
llm: Nasreen Parveen decided to run for president of her high school's student council.
But the only way she could win was if she took control—and that meant doing something she had never done before.
Nasreen is a Pakistani American Muslim teenager who lives in Chicago.
Her essay won first place in our 2016 Scholastic Art & Writing Awards.

human: I’ve written several times about the case for disqualifying Donald Trump via the 14th Amendment, arguing that it fails tests of political prudence and constitutional plausibility alike.

But the debate keeps going, and the proponents of disqualification have dug into the position that whatever the prudential concerns about the amendment’s application, the events of Jan. 6, 2021, obviously amounted to an insurrection in the sense intended by the Constitution, and saying otherwise is just evasion or denial.
llm: I’ve written several times about the protests that took place in Paris on January 6, 2015 — and I have been careful to refer to them as “protests” rather than “riots.”
That was not simply a matter of semantics: in fact, I went out of my way to avoid the term “riot,” because there was no rioting going on that day.

human: The reimagined home in Australia is ‘just joyful and really easy to live in.’
llm: The reimagined home features a series of outdoor spaces that are linked to the interior through a glass wall.

human: Some candidates sound promising on paper but fall short when put to the test.
llm: Some candidates sound great on the stump, but in reality they're just not ready for primetime.
Here are some of the worst.

human: A demonstration last week involving butchering half an heirloom pig, and showing how to use various parts, kicked off a series in the basement workshop and bakery at Leland Eating and Drinking House in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn.
It was followed by a five-course tasting dinner in the wine cellar, starring pork.

The restaurant, which does its own butchering as a matter of course, has scheduled subsequent classes monthly throughout the year, with the next one on Feb. 21, followed by March 13, both pork-centric.
Later in the year there will be sessions about duck and fish.
The classes and dinners, starting at 6 p.m., are $100 plus tax, tip and beverages.
llm: A demonstration last week of the new cooking style, butchery-before-dinner, at Leland Eating & Drinking House in Portland, Oregon.

human: Microsoft, the technology giant that ranks as one of the world’s most valuable companies, was shaken by the upheaval at OpenAI, the small but influential artificial intelligence start-up that developed the ChatGPT chatbot, before it found a way out of the turmoil that propelled its shares to a new high.
llm: Microsoft, the technology giant that has been steadily increasing its presence in the AI space since CEO Satya Nadella took over, has just hired three of the most prominent researchers in the field: Ian Goodfellow, David Ha and Andrew Ilyas.

human: Shortly after Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, friends and relatives of Gali Shlezinger Idan, who lived in a kibbutz near the Gaza border, received frantic messages to check her Facebook page.
llm: Shortly after Hamas terrorists took over a bus, hijacking the passengers and murdering one of them in an attack that made headlines around the world, the terror group used social media accounts belonging to those on board to spread its propaganda.

human: The new report in The New York Times that Russia is quietly signaling a readiness to freeze the war in Ukraine is both suspicious and tantalizing.
llm: The new report of the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) provides details on how pro-Russian separatists are recruiting children as young as 15 for military operations.
The HRMMU has documented a total of 464 cases of child recruitment and use by both sides.
However, it also reports that there is no evidence of systematic or widespread recruitment of children.

human: The Chargers now have a 39% chance to make the playoffs.

human: In more than 1,500 animal species, from crickets and sea urchins to bottlenose dolphins and bonobos, scientists have observed sexual encounters between members of the same sex.
llm: In more than 150 species of mammal, males have been observed engaging in sexual behaviors with other males.
A new study from the University of California, Los Angeles suggests that same-sex behavior evolved in many mammalian lineages as a way to reduce conflict among males.

human: In our age of scorched-earth ground offensives and bombed-out hospitals, the prospect of punishing atrocities perpetrated by governments seems particularly distant.
But you could be forgiven for thinking otherwise based on the recent bounty of acclaimed books that glorify the potential of international treaties and tribunals to make lasting peace.
Suspicious of diplomatic horse-trading, a prominent segment of Western liberals champion international law as the most promising means to enact their ideal of a just world.
llm: In our age of human rights, it is hard to remember that as recently as 1945 war crimes were dealt with primarily by summary execution.
But this was how things worked in the aftermath of World War II.
In the years since then, however, a new international system has grown up to deal with these issues.

human: Her grandfather founded the outfitting giant L.L. Bean, whose gear has become synonymous with a woodsy lifestyle.
She became a force in lobstering and tourism with companies of her own, and a lightning rod for critics who object to her outspoken conservative views.
llm: Her grandfather founded the company.

human: There is one particular pulsar, a type of quick-spinning dead star, that holds the current record for the fastest rotation of any celestial body in the known universe — 716 times per second.

By contrast, the blade of a Vitamix can turn around 333 times every second, but a blender is small enough to sit on a countertop, and a pulsar is a city-size ball of neutrons that floats in space and contains the mass of half a million Earths.
llm: There is one thing that I have to ask.
How can the Universe be expanding if it has a flat geometry?
As far as I understand, an infinite Euclidean space expands or contracts by definition, but an infinite hyperbolic space remains the same size.
So how can the Universe expand if it is flat?
Or am I missing something?

human: New Zealand’s new right-wing government has said it will repeal a law that would have gradually banned all cigarette sales in the country over the course of several decades.
llm: New Zealand’s new government says it will scrap a smoking ban in public places.

human: The catchy, folk-tinged numbers from “Treason the Musical” have been streamed online over a million times, in 96 countries.
Its fans — known as “Plotters” — have been listening to an EP, an acoustic record and a live album of the songs, as well as sharing their own performances on TikTok.
But until this fall, there hadn’t even been a full-scale production of the show.
llm: The catchy, folk-tinged songs have a lot of energy, and the cast is good.

human: For Jeanette Winterson, ghost stories are not old-fashioned or anachronistic in the modern world, but both cutting-edge and primal.

In the introduction to her new collection, NIGHT SIDE OF THE RIVER: Ghost Stories (Grove, 306 pp., $27), she recalls some of her own inexplicable experiences with the uncanny, from the ghost of a writer friend materializing on her computer screen to her childhood premonition of her grandmother’s passing.
Religion, and specifically faith in an afterlife, “can be considered as humankind’s first disruptive start-up,” she writes.
“What’s being disrupted is death.”
llm: For Jeanette Winterson, the literary imagination is boundless.
In her new novel, The Daylight Gate, she writes of witches, alchemists and religious fanatics in a dark tale that blurs the lines between reality and fantasy.
She tells us why the ghosts of the past are always with us, even as we imagine a different future.

human: Do you know what a Zynbabwe is?
Or an upper-decky lip pillow?
OK, here’s an easier one — how about just Zyn?
llm: Do you know what your kids are doing online?
The Internet is such an integral part of children's lives today that it can be hard to keep up.
Technology expert Dr. Timothy Cigelske helps parents understand the online world and provides suggestions for how to help kids make smart choices online.

human: A man who had been denied probation attacked a judge during his sentencing in a Nevada courtroom on Wednesday in a violent episode that was captured on video.
llm: A man who was denied probation by a Las Vegas judge attacked the judge Wednesday, hitting him with a chair and punching him before being subdued.

human: Since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, President Biden has presented himself as a statesman humbled and enlightened by his own country’s missteps after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

human: Spirit Airlines, once a fast-growing low-cost carrier, is struggling to convince investors that it has a clear path forward after an antitrust ruling blocked the sale of the company to JetBlue Airways.

human: One Friday earlier this month, just as Dr. Daouda Diallo stepped out of the passport office in the capital of the West African nation of Burkina Faso, four men grabbed him off the street, pushed him into a vehicle and drove off.

human: The vote on Tuesday to remove Representative Kevin McCarthy as speaker of the House of Representatives has left the chamber mired in chaos.

human: President Biden pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday to agree to the creation of a Palestinian state after the war in Gaza is over and raised options that would limit Palestinian sovereignty to make the prospect more palatable to Israel.
llm: President Biden pressed Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to move toward the creation of an independent Palestinian state.

human: On a Cape Cod beach last January, I braced for my daily cold water plunge.
“Can I join you?” asked a stranger.
I hesitated.
But her red hair and wide smile reminded me of my younger self.
“Sure,” I said.
Ashley is 29.
For seven minutes in frigid water, we shared our stories: her chronic illness and career change; my failed marriage and struggles raising a child with cancer.
Every day since our first encounter, we’ve met to immerse ourselves in the ocean.
We bond in a daily baptism.
I now can’t imagine braving water, or life, without her.
— Amy McHugh
llm: On a Cape Town beach, I meet the man of my dreams.

human: On a recent trip to the Caribbean island of Antigua, Melissa Middlestadt, a writer from the Toronto area, was charged a $12-a-night resort fee by the all-inclusive Jolly Beach.

llm: On a recent trip to Las Vegas, I was reminded of the frustration that travelers feel when they are hit with mandatory resort fees.
While I knew about them in advance and had factored it into my budget, I was still annoyed when I checked out.
And rightfully so!
This is a perfect example of how hotels are taking advantage of consumers who don’t know their rights.

human: Dexter Scott King, who as one of four children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. worked closely with — but also frequently fought against — his siblings and the civil rights community over his father’s legacy, died on Monday at his home in Malibu, Calif.

llm: Dexter Scott King, the youngest son of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Coretta Scott King, who was a prominent voice in his father’s civil rights movement and went on to lead the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, died Friday in Atlanta.

human: We could talk, I suppose, about all Taylor Swift’s done for the economy, friendship bracelets, seismology and Travis Kelce.

On a 50-foot screen, the various apertures of her mouth constitute a spectacle.
There’s the “Who?
Me?,”
the “yeah I said it,” the “ouch,” the “ooooo,” the “gosh golly” and the “Sally Field wins another Oscar.”
Hers is the story of “oh.”
llm: We could talk, but we don't talk enough.

human: What makes a house a home?

human: On the Friday before Labor Day, Joseph Lanni and Vincent Minsquero stopped into Roxy’s Bar and Grille in Toms River, N.J.

human: House Republicans, divided and demoralized after the ouster of their speaker this week, are now quietly feuding over how to elect a successor.
llm: House Republicans, divided over how to replace Speaker John A. Boehner, are struggling with how to proceed in choosing his successor amid growing doubts that their favorite, Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, will prevail.

human: A foreign visitor walking through Praça Brasil, a leafy square in the Amazonian port city of Belém, might think that the whirring blenders at a dozen nearby food carts were creating the most authentic açaí bowls on earth.
llm: A foreign visitor once told me that if I ever wanted to see a real rain forest, then I should visit the Amazon River basin in South America.
I replied that I had already seen one here in Malaysia, and he was rather surprised at my comment.
In fact, he seemed quite disbelieving until I took him on a tour of the Taman Negara National Park which is the oldest tropical rain forest in the world.

human: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.

human: Louis Vuitton’s takeover of the sporting world continues apace: Next August, shortly after the LVMH-sponsored Summer Olympic Games end in Paris, the Louis Vuitton-sponsored America’s Cup will begin in Barcelona.

human: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

human: “If you make it to the U.S., then you’re more likely than not to be able to stay.

human: The first large offshore wind farm in New England has started producing electricity, a milestone for an industry that has struggled to get off the ground over the past year.

human: The Italian Alps are renowned for their stunning scenery, fine wine and good food.
But many travelers are unaware that the region also hosts exquisite Renaissance and Baroque art.

Nestled in the mountains and hills of northwestern Italy, just an hour’s drive from Milan, a cluster of Catholic sanctuaries brim with sculptures and frescoes by artists like Gaudenzio Ferrari, Tanzio da Varallo and Pier Francesco Mazzucchelli.
llm: The Italian Alps are home to some of the most beautiful lakes, valleys and villages in all of Europe.
This trip offers you a chance to enjoy them all on a 10-day journey through Italy’s northern mountain region.
Beginning in Venice, we visit historic cities like Verona, Bolzano and Trento, and make our way into the heart of the Dolomites.
We will spend time exploring Lake Garda, the largest lake in Italy, and the smaller but equally stunning Lake Braies, as well as the towns and villages nestled in their foothills.
The spectacular scenery of the Dolomite mountains is reason enough to go there, but we also want to get a taste of the culture of this region.
From the architecture of its churches

human: The Israeli military’s seizure of Al-Shifa Hospital, Gaza’s largest medical complex, is central to the military strategy at the heart of the ground invasion:

llm: The Israeli military’s strategy for Operation Protective Edge is a bit more complex than it appears at first glance.
But the question remains, will it work?
In an interview with the Jerusalem Post, Major General Sami Turgeman, the head of Southern Command, said that he wants to “eradicate” Hamas from Gaza.

human: Hollywood’s movie factories run on conventional wisdom — entrenched notions, based on experience, about what types of films are likely to pop at the global box office.
llm: Hollywood’s movie factories are trying to figure out what went wrong with their plans for 2020.
The box office was a disaster, with domestic ticket sales down by nearly $1 billion from 2019.
