human: Bret Stephens: Gail, my attention these past few weeks has been devoted almost entirely to outrages and tragedies in the Middle East.

llm: Bret Stephens: Gail, I know you are an avid follower of politics.

human: Michael Bennett, the former N.F.L. player, started designing furniture as a way to reconsider architecture and the spaces that Black people occupy.

Inspired by his upbringing in Louisiana and Texas, as well as by trips to Senegal, where his ancestors are from, Bennett began to think about the objects that “bring Black people together in public spaces” as a way to deepen his longtime activism work focused on racial justice.
After retiring from football in 2020, he founded the design practice Studio Kër.

Bennett’s exploration of the Black home led him to create an 11-piece collection of sculptural furniture that he’s debuting this month in “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib,” his inaugural exhibition for the Los Angeles art gallery Marta, presented at Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation in Chicago.
(In the spring, the show will travel to Houston.)

The collection reimagines objects of communal gatherings; pieces include the Gumbo lounge chair, a lush take on the stackable monobloc chair, and the Pew couch, a nod to the church bench, made of leather and ekki wood.
“For me, the show is about celebrating Black ingenuity and connecting back to that African diasporic design language,” says Bennett.
“We Gotta Get Back to the Crib” is on view from Jan. 12 through Feb. 10, marta.la.
llm: Michael Bennett, the defensive end for the Seattle Seahawks, has had an eventful offseason—he recently wrote about his experience being racially profiled by Las Vegas police in February and then arrested (the charges were later dropped).
He’s also become a prominent advocate for social justice causes, from Black Lives Matter to women’s rights.

human: Phyllis Coates, who played the reporter Lois Lane, one of the most enduring characters in popular culture, in a theatrical film and the first season of the popular “Adventures of Superman” television series, died on Wednesday in Woodland Hills, Calif.

llm: Phyllis Coates, who played reporter Lois Lane in the first season of “The Adventures of Superman,” a television series that ran from 1952 to 1958 and made her a household name, died on April 5 at her home in Los Angeles.

Ms. Coates was best known for playing the Daily Planet newspaper reporter alongside George Reeves as Clark Kent/Superman and Jack Larson as Jimmy Olsen.
The show, which ran in syndication, was filmed in black-and-white with a budget that was limited to the costumes — the superhero’s iconic red cape and blue suit, and Lane

human: We know — 2023 isn’t over yet.
There are still many holiday parties and cookie swaps and family dinners to barrel through.

human: In recent years, much of my life as a consumer has shifted to what I like to call background spending.

human: On the day before my sister Julie died, I lay down on her bed and held her gingerly in my arms, afraid that any pressure would hurt her.

Her abdomen looked like the lunar landscape, with protrusions everywhere, the sources of her pain plainly visible.
llm: On the day she died, my sister wrote a letter to me.

“I have always been so lucky,” she wrote.

human: The complex dance of doubt and religious faith is frequently cast in terms of a quest.

One might be “on a faith journey,” or be “a lost soul,” or be “searching” for meaning and the divine — all images derived from the idea of starting at one place, keeping your eyes open, and ending up, ultimately, in some final destination.
Small wonder that many human cultures imagine a wander in the wilderness, literal or metaphorical, as pivotal to one’s initiation into maturity.
Some fresh wisdom and revelation comes from walking around in circles for a while.
llm: The complex dance, which is performed by seven dancers and three musicians, is an exploration of spirituality.
The piece was inspired by Ms. Ristow’s experience with the death of her father in 2015.
She found herself wandering through life in search of answers to some of life’s most difficult questions.
“I don’t know if there are any answers,” she said.
“But I have to try.”

human: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo talks about flamenco, it often sounds as though she is describing something springing from beneath her feet.

human: Modestly scaled and tonally perfect, “Fallen Leaves” opens in a fluorescent hell-on-earth and ends with a vision of something like paradise.

A lot of the drinks are downed hurriedly and often furtively by a man, while elsewhere a woman listens to sad songs.
Outwardly, these two are leading lives of quiet desperation, though because this is an Aki Kaurismaki movie, their despair comes with great comic timing.
llm: Modestly scaled and shot in a flat, hand-held style, “Fallen Leaves” is a simple story with an uncomplicated moral.

human: For a decade, it was easy to get help repairing an iPhone.

human: The origin of this seasonal slasher is in an ersatz trailer the horror filmmaker Eli Roth made for the portmanteau movie “Grindhouse” in 2007.

Al Jean and Mike Reiss were trying to come up with a Halloween-themed episode for season 2 but couldn’t find any ideas that worked (which might explain why they ended up doing “Treehouse of Horror” in the first place).
So instead, they decided to write an episode set on Thanksgiving…which was a few months away at the time.
The writers even joked about the premise being “too specific”.

human: In September, I went to see Counting Crows, a band whose music formed the soundtrack of my adolescence.

human: It is a truth universally acknowledged that meat tastes better when seasoned ahead.

llm: It is a very good thing that I am not in charge of anything.

human: When people ask me what my favorite horror movie is, John Carpenter’s groundbreaking shocker comes out on top.
Jamie Lee Curtis plays a high schooler who gets stalked on Halloween night by an escaped lunatic named Michael Myers.
Today it sounds like any old horror movie.

But Carpenter was prophetic with narrative choices that horror now takes for granted: a masked killing-machine villain, a strong-willed final girl next door, creatively depicted deaths, touches of dark comedy.
(And a score that sounds like a chase.)
Together they make “Halloween” my top Halloween treat.
llm: When people ask me what my favorite movie is, I usually respond with something like “I’m not sure I can answer that” or “It depends on the day.”

human: For more than a quarter century, the fortunes of the United States and China were fused in a uniquely monumental joint venture.
llm: For more than 30 years, the BMW-Rover alliance was a textbook example of successful joint ventures.

What lessons can be learned from this failure?

human: Gov. Kathy Hochul threatened on Thursday to fine several hospital systems if they did not quickly reopen psychiatric wards that had closed at the height of the pandemic, saying that those units were now urgently needed to provide treatment to homeless people with severe mental illness.
llm: Gov. Kathy Hochul is putting the state's hospitals on notice that they could face fines if they don't reopen their shuttered psychiatric units or build new ones.
The governor said she wants to see a plan from each hospital by Oct. 15 to address the issue of the shortage of beds for people in mental health crisis.
"We are going to be holding you accountable," Hochul told hospital executives at a meeting Wednesday in Albany.

human: Until 2011, conscription was mandatory for German men, with the option to refuse armed service and do civil service at home or abroad instead.
In 2009 at age 19, I chose to go abroad as part of a development aid program, hoping that I would have the opportunity to contribute meaningfully to a community.
I went to Senegal for a one-year civil service assignment for a German nongovernmental organization that I picked from a list of options provided by a ministry’s website.
llm: Until 2011, conscription in Israel was compulsory for most Israeli citizens over the age of 18 (women were exempt unless they volunteered), with some religious exceptions and those engaged in Yeshiva study.
Conscientious objectors could opt out of military service if they agreed to an alternative civilian service.
This option is open to all Israeli citizens regardless of religion or gender, including Arabs.
As of 2015, military conscription is not mandatory for women but it remains mandatory for men.

human: Q: I’m in my 50s, and I’ve heard that it’s normal to burn fewer calories as I get older.

llm: Q: I’m in my 40s and have been working out for years.

human: It took the Pentagon three and a half days to inform the White House that Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had been hospitalized on New Year’s Day following complications from an elective procedure, two U.S. officials said Saturday.
llm: It took the media and White House by surprise, but it shouldn't have.
Defense Sec.
Robert Gates is 67 years old, and as such, he is on the cusp of needing medical care that many senior citizens require at some point or another.

human: A proposed carbon pipeline could cut through Thomas Fehr’s Iowa farmland.

llm: A proposed carbon tax bill in the U.S. Congress has received a good deal of support from environmental groups and economists, but is opposed by many fossil fuel companies and members of Congress.
In this post, I'll outline some of the pros and cons of the carbon tax concept, and how it would work if implemented.

human: Mia Rodriguez was 7 when she first went to Art Basel Miami Beach.

human: In the wake of Sandra Day O’Connor’s passing, I saw a photo of her with my father, Ronald Reagan, after he had nominated her to be the first woman on the Supreme Court.

llm: In the wake of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's announcement that her husband has Alzheimer's disease and she is retiring from public life to care for him, David Von Drehle writes in this week's Time magazine:

human: In 2015, Pope Francis came out as an environmentalist, with his landmark encyclical Laudato Si, later called by Bill McKibben “the most important document yet of this millennium” and by Pankaj Mishra “arguably the most important piece of intellectual criticism in our time.”
llm: In 2015, Pope Francis issued a landmark encyclical on the environment.
He called on people around the world to take action on climate change—and for governments and businesses to act immediately to reduce carbon emissions.
We talk with Naomi Klein about how the Pope is raising awareness about the connection between climate change and inequality.
She says that the Pope's message has inspired her to become more active in the fight against global warming.

human: With dire warnings of planetary catastrophe and urgent pleas to protect vulnerable populations, world leaders on Friday implored one another to stop burning fossil fuels and swiftly reduce the greenhouse gas emissions that are `dangerously heating the planet.

human: Trick or treat!

human: Julvonnia McDowell was making dinner one evening when she got a call saying that her 14-year-old son, JaJuan — a gentle boy who loved animals, who was so generous that he gave a pair of shoes to a classmate who was being teased — had been shot.

llm: A new poll shows that 80% of Saudis are opposed to any normalization with the Jewish State.

human: Five years ago, what would become the deadliest wildfire in California history erupted in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.

human: Philip Glass wanted to become a better pianist.

human: Brad Meltzer has experience with ownership in publishing.

human: This house is in Potrero Hill, about a 10-minute walk from Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center.

llm: This house is located on a cliff overlooking the ocean, and it's quite large, with 14,000 square feet of living space.

There are 5 fireplaces throughout the house, as well as a private elevator that will take you to all four levels of the residence.
Outside there's a swimming pool, spa, a tennis court, a basketball court, and a putting green.
The property also has a guesthouse that features a full kitchen.
This house can be yours for $3 million.

human: A Canadian court found that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s use of the country’s Emergencies Act to end a truck convoy protest that had paralyzed the capital, Ottawa, two years ago was an unjustified infringement of civil rights, including the protection against unreasonable search and seizure, and, in some instances, the freedom of expression as well.

human: There were an estimated 249 million cases of malaria around the globe last year, the World Health Organization said on Thursday, significantly more than before the Covid-19 pandemic and an increase of five million over 2021.

human: The Kenyan force tasked with leading a mission to take back Haiti’s streets from violent gangs that have overtaken much of the country’s capital will be made up of police officers who have a checkered history of their own at home, accused of killing more than 100 people this year and lobbing tear-gas into a school during anti-government demonstrations.
llm: The Kenyan force is the only UN military operation led by an African nation.
It was established in 1997 after years of civil war between two rebel groups and the Sudanese government.

In November, Human Rights Watch released a report accusing Ugandan troops of sexual violence against women and girls in South Sudan, including rape and forced marriage.
The Ugandans denied the allegations.

human: Amid the 1970s television landscape selling obvious sex and youth, Norman Lear understood the magnetism of older everyday women.

The article highlights how these women broke through gender stereotypes, and discusses their continued influence today.

human: The Supreme Court justices seemed divided on Monday over a fiercely contested bankruptcy settlement for Purdue Pharma that would funnel billions of dollars into addressing the opioid epidemic in exchange for shielding members of the wealthy Sackler family from related civil lawsuits.

human: Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip “will not be returned alive” unless Israeli forces leave, a Hamas spokesman said on Wednesday, highlighting the predicament facing the Israeli government: It has vowed to free the hostages, and to pursue the war and defeat Hamas.
llm: Israeli hostages held by Hamas will not be released until the IDF withdraws from the Gaza Strip, a senior Hamas leader said Thursday.

human: No sooner did Mayor Eric Adams of New York land in Washington, D.C., on city business Thursday than he had to turn right back around to take care of his own.

human: Ms. Haley, the former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said that there would be no Hamas without Iran.
llm: Ms. Haley, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, said at a Security Council meeting on Friday that the Trump administration “strongly and unequivocally” supported Israel in its fight against Hamas, the militant Islamist group that controls the Gaza Strip.

human: Hollywood horror often attempts to work out collective anxiety about the suburbs, that place full of pleasant-looking houses creaking with ghosts and terrors.
Suburban life is, admittedly, fundamentally strange, with neighborhoods full of atomized worlds and natural features turned into individual, highly-controlled assets.
A forest becomes manicured bushes.
A lake becomes a pool.
llm: Hollywood horror often seems to be at a crossroads between the old and the new.
On one hand, we have the classic stylings of the genre, with movies like A Quiet Place, Hereditary or The Witch.
On the other, we have the modernized “jump scare” movies, like Insidious, Saw, or the Conjuring franchise.
Night Swim is more in line with the latter than the former, but it has some good ideas that help it stand out from the crowd.

human: Donald J. Trump has decided not to return to the witness stand to testify on Monday as he had planned, setting up an abrupt and anticlimactic ending to the defense’s case in his civil fraud trial in Manhattan.
llm: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, will not testify on Tuesday morning as scheduled in a civil fraud trial involving one of his signature businesses, the now-defunct Trump University.

human: Zvi Zamir, who as the director of Israel’s Mossad spy agency led a violent campaign to crush Palestinian terrorism after 11 Israelis were killed at the 1972 Munich Summer Olympics — and who a year later relayed a warning to his government that Egypt and Syria were about to start the Yom Kippur War but was not taken seriously — died on Jan. 2.
He was 98.
llm: Zvi Zamir, who was the head of Israel's foreign intelligence service, Mossad, from 1968 to 1974 and played a pivotal role in bringing down the Munich massacre terrorists, died on July 3.
He was 98.
His death was announced by his family.
Mr. Zamir was head of Mossad when Palestinian terrorists murdered 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich.
He oversaw the operation that tracked down and killed those responsible for the attack.

human: Strong winds damaged resorts along the coast of Acapulco, Mexico, near where Otis made landfall.

human: Nio, a Chinese electric car company that competes with Tesla, employs 11,000 people in research and development, but sold a mere 8,000 cars per month from April through June.

human: More than a year and a half after Amazon workers on Staten Island voted to form the company’s first union in the United States, the company appears to be taking a harder line toward labor organizing, disciplining workers and even firing one who had been heavily involved in the union campaign.
llm: More than a decade after the Supreme Court ruled that Wal-Mart could not be held liable for gender discrimination because of company policy, Wal-Mart is being sued by employees who say they were victims of racial discrimination.

The suit was filed in federal court in Florida and says managers and supervisors used racially derogatory terms when talking about minority employees and that the company has not done enough to address racial discrimination complaints.
In addition, it claims that black workers were disciplined more harshly than white ones and paid less than whites with similar qualifications.

human: With its wooded hills, winding roads and shimmering lakes and reservoirs, Ringwood, N.J., feels more like the Catskills than like a New Jersey suburb.
That rural charm was what attracted Linda and James Pentifallo when they decided to leave their longtime home in River Edge, in Bergen County.
llm: With its wooded hills and small farms, Ringwood, a borough in northern New Jersey, is a world away from the nearby cityscapes of Manhattan and Paterson.

It has an almost rustic atmosphere, with many homes having acre-size lots.

human: Patrick Page and Paige Davis met in the mid 1990s, during New York rehearsals for the first national tour of the musical “Beauty and the Beast.”

llm: Patrick Page and Mary Beth Peil in Follies.

human: Q: We live on the first and second floors of a brownstone in East Harlem, and we love the backyard.
Two buildings over, a neighbor in the second-floor apartment has put a litter box on the fire escape outside their window for community cats to shelter.
The neighbor also puts out food for them.
In the morning, there are usually half a dozen adult cats lingering around the box and the stairs.
Inevitably, they end up roaming in our backyard, peeing, pooping and fighting.
The odor in the summer is terrible.
We’ve had two female cats give birth in our backyard this year alone.
The kittens are cute, their cries not so much.
What can we do?
llm: Q: We live in a nice community.
Everyone is friendly and respectful of each other’s property.
Unfortunately, we have one neighbor who lets his cat run free at all hours of the day and night.
This cat has been coming into our yard for months now, using it as its own personal bathroom.
I know that sounds disgusting, but it’s true!
I’ve tried everything to get rid of this cat—pepper spray, water guns, even putting up “Beware of Dog” signs.
Nothing works.
What do you suggest?

human: Conservatives thrust the House back into chaos on Wednesday, grinding business to a halt in protest of the spending deal Speaker Mike Johnson struck with Democrats to avert a government shutdown and leaving the funding package in limbo.

human: Long before he was switch-hitting for the New York Yankees, a young Mickey Mantle was taking swings against his right-handed father and his left-handed grandfather in front of a shed next to his family’s humble 670-square-foot house in tiny Commerce, Okla.
More often than not, the young slugger would knock the pitches clear over the house’s roof.
Sometimes he’d smack line drives into the side of the rusted shed, where visible dings in the walls remain to this day.
llm: Long before he became a legend, Mickey Mantle grew up in this two-bedroom home in Commerce, Okla.
Now, it can be yours for just $7.

human: In charting the flight of the battery-powered CX300 aircraft recently, The New York Times was back where it has spent a lot of time over the last 120 years: in the clouds.
llm: In charting the history of aviation, it is easy to focus on the “firsts”: first flight, first non-stop transcontinental flight, first jet airliner, etc.
But that is only part of the story.
This presentation will look at the other side of aviation history—the industry’s role in the popular culture of the 20th century.
From the early days when barnstormers were as famous as movie stars to the era of Pan Am and TWA, aviation was more than just news.
It was a lifestyle choice for many people who wanted to see the world or escape from it.
In addition to covering the role of commercial airlines, the presentation will also explore the role played by aircraft manufacturers, air

human: Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas is facing some of the sharpest scrutiny of her early tenure after a public records request revealed that her office bought a lectern for $19,000 — and a whistle-blower accused the office of altering records to cover up the spending.
llm: Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders' father, Mike Huckabee, is on record as saying he will not vote for Donald Trump.

human: Have you ever spent quality time with a chicken?
I raised them as a teenager, and I do not particularly recommend it.
They can be smelly and dirty.
They’re honestly not very bright.
Yet they’re like living cartoons, weird and funny to watch, with spindly little legs holding up plump little bodies.
They cluck disapprovingly when you take their eggs, and they’ll eat anything you dump in their yard (including, uh, chicken).
llm: Have you ever been to a water park?
It can be a lot of fun.
There are water slides and splash pads, pools and lazy rivers.
But it’s also kind of like being at school: there are rules to follow and people telling you what to do all day long.
And then there’s that moment when you finally get your lunch break, but all they have is chicken nuggets.
Every day.
All summer.
That’s what inspired our new musical comedy, “Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget.”
The show was first developed by me, my brother Jake, and our friend Kevin at the New York Musical Festival in 2015.
Then it moved to Playwrights Horizons in 2016 before making its way

human: In frantic talks, and with an Israeli ground invasion looming, officials from the U.S. and Middle Eastern countries, including Egypt, sought to ease what Israeli officials have called the “siege” of Gaza.

Read the latest from the crisis.

human: Violence in the West Bank, where millions of Palestinians live under Israeli military occupation, continues to simmer amid the war in Gaza.

llm: Violence in the West Bank has been rising since July, when Israel launched a massive military offensive against Hamas militants who rule the coastal territory.

human: After years of rising overdoses and an exodus of business from central Portland, Gov. Tina Kotek of Oregon said on Monday that state and city officials are proposing to roll back a portion of the nation’s most wide-ranging drug decriminalization law in a bid to revive the troubled city.

They want to make it illegal for people to use drugs in public.

The proposal is one of many efforts in the United States to combat addiction by using the criminal justice system to discourage people from shooting up or snorting drugs in parks, on sidewalks and along busy streets.
In New Hampshire, lawmakers recently passed legislation that makes it a crime to knowingly allow drug use on private property.
In Florida, state attorneys are pursuing cases against dealers and users who contributed to fatal overdoses.
And in several cities, including Seattle, police officers are being trained to use naloxone, a

human: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor seeking the Republican Party’s presidential nomination, appears to have weathered a holiday-season gaffe on the causes of the Civil War, but the controversy over her answer, which neglected to mention slavery, was a gift to a rival, former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.
llm: Nikki Haley, the South Carolina governor who is running for president, has made a habit of talking about her state’s role in the American Civil War.

On Thursday night, at an event in Charleston, she spoke to an audience of business leaders and political operatives about her home state’s “darkest days”—the moment when Confederate troops fired on Fort Sumter, at the mouth of the harbor.
It was April 12, 1861: the start of the war that would eventually end slavery.

human: A college student with a heart condition died after she drank a heavily caffeinated drink from Panera Bread, likely thinking it had a safe amount of caffeine, her parents said in a lawsuit filed on Monday.

human: The American ambassador to NATO said on Tuesday that U.S. military assistance to Israel after the weekend attacks by Hamas assailants would not come at Ukraine’s expense.

human: Early in the pandemic, as in-person art fairs ground to halt, many art professionals proclaimed the financial, health and climate costs of shipping art and people around the planet were simply no longer sustainable.

This topic was the subject of a great deal of discussion at the recent CEO Forum hosted by the National Art Services Coalition and Americans for the Arts.

human: Ten finance guys are drinking in a bar.

There were no injuries among the 143 passengers or six crew members on board, according to the airline.
The plane had departed at 5:20 p.m. and was headed for Fort Lauderdale, Fla., when the pilot decided to turn back because of the problem with the landing gear, the airline said.
“Our maintenance team is investigating what appears to be a mechanical issue,” the

human: As a presidential candidate, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has said he would authorize the use of deadly force against people crossing the border, seek to end the practice of birthright citizenship and send the military to strike against drug cartels inside Mexico, a key ally of the United States, even without the permission of its government.
llm: As a presidential candidate, Donald Trump made clear that he intended to deport undocumented immigrants who had committed crimes in the United States.
He also vowed to end birthright citizenship.
Now, as president, he has acted on both of those promises.

human: A Black high school student in Texas who had been suspended because of how he wears his hair was removed from his school on Wednesday and transferred to a disciplinary school program, according to a letter from the school district shared by the student’s family.

human: I write these lines from Jerusalem, after spending time with the families of some of the 240 people kidnapped by Hamas terrorists on Oct. 7.
The hostages now held in Gaza include Jewish Israelis, Muslim Israelis and foreign citizens of different ethnicities.
llm: I write these words at the start of the third week of Operation Protective Edge.
The past three weeks have been very difficult for the State of Israel.
Our soldiers, airmen and sailors are fighting heroically against Hamas in Gaza.
As of this writing, they have struck over 4,000 targets in Gaza.
But we know that even if our forces uncover and destroy every single tunnel, rocket arsenal and terrorist base, there can be no peace so long as Hamas continues to seek the destruction of Israel.

human: Can you find Kyrgyzstan on a map?

llm: Can you find Bishkek on a map?

human: Amid growing despair and rage, Arab countries including Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt are intensifying their appeals to the U.S. to pressure Israel for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza.

llm: Amid growing despair over the prospects for peace, Israeli and Palestinian leaders have begun a new round of direct negotiations.

In this edition of the Wednesday Briefing, MEI experts discuss the factors that could derail or support progress in these talks, the influence of regional events on the process, and the potential consequences of failure.

human: The moon stands alone.
It is unique in the known cosmos: a solitary rock one-fourth the width of its host planet, the only place life has ever been found.
And the moon is alone: It is a desolate, sunbaked and crater-pocked wasteland that harbors little except what we bring to it, either with our minds or with our spaceships.
But that is about to change.
llm: The moon stands alone.

human: Eight years ago, just before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump crowed about his invulnerability.
llm: Eight years ago, Donald Trump tweeted: “We should just go in and take the oil.”
In 2016, he told the Wall Street Journal that the U.S. should have kept Iraq’s oil and gas after invading the country.
Last week, he said it again.
This time, however, there was a twist.

human: A change taking place right now has the potential to do more good within U.S. prisons than any policy in a generation — good that will extend far beyond the realm of criminal justice.

human: Some new restaurants are opportunistic, the result of circumstance.
Others, like the Danish chef Mads Refslund’s new Brooklyn project, are years in the planning — eight years exactly, said Mr. Refslund, a founder of Noma in Copenhagen.
What he set out to achieve is a fluid fine-dining concept, where the cooks are the servers.
“Everyone is a cook,” he said.
“They can best explain the food to the customers, but turning cooks into waiters is a challenge.”
There are 26 of them, all dressed in black and rotating their stations.

They’re in full view at work: The dining room amounts to a huge square kitchen, surrounded by 58 counter and table seats, and a bar and a lounge in an industrial space — previously a rubber factory — with a white brick 1930s facade.
The restaurant’s menu lists ingredients, each of which can be ordered, in consultation with a cook/waiter, hot or cold, grilled or chilled, or, as the name has it, fire (ild in Danish) and ice (is).
The only meat options are sustainable American bison and venison.
Custom carts bearing produce and seafood snacks to start a meal (priced per item) patrol the dining area.
The menu is à la carte with a minimum of five dishes per person ($150); some are served family-style.
The 18-seat bar also serves food with no minimum requirement.

Among the dishes devised by Mr. Refslund and Bryce Shuman, his chef de cuisine (who knows his way around a grill if his food at Sweetbriar, his previous gig, is any indication), are Shigoku oysters with green almonds and cucumber, venison tartare wrapped in beet rosettes, tuna lightly roasted on kombu, grilled wild duck with plum juice, grilled sea scallop dumplings, surf clam shells sealed to form a vessel and filled with clam and tomato water to drink, and smoked barbecued eel.
On Sundays, meals are served family style, starting at noon, no reservations.
(Opens Wednesday)

human: The first several minutes of Adrian Murray’s cringe comedy take place in a single, uninterrupted shot.

Even as the film eventually moves on to multiple other locations, including Molly’s apartment, her office and her ex-boyfriend’s home, we never truly leave those initial minutes in the car.

The incident takes over Molly’s entire life as she becomes increasingly obsessed with fighting the ticket — re-enacting the scenario repeatedly, doing the rounds of traffic court and talking her friends’ and co-workers’ ears off about the wrongs of the system.
llm: The first several minutes of Theeb are set in the desolate deserts of Jordan.
The camera pans across sandy terrain and we hear nothing but the wind.
This is an effective way to establish the film’s setting, and it also serves as a perfect introduction to the movie’s protagonist, Theeb (Jacir Eid Al-Hwietat).
After his older brother Hussein (Hussein Salameh Al-Sweilhiyeen) abandons him in the desert, Theeb must rely on his own wits and skills to survive.

human: The sounds of battle echo on both sides of Israel’s northern border with Lebanon.
Sirens blare in Israeli towns, warning of incoming rockets fired by Lebanon’s Hezbollah militant group.
Lebanese civilians have fled their villages, fearing Israeli shelling and the possibility of a new war.
llm: The sounds of war are everywhere in Beirut.
But as Israeli jets drop their deadly payloads on targets across Lebanon, there is a sense that this time, it's different.
It's not just that the destruction has been so much worse than before -- although that is certainly true.

The last war between Hezbollah and Israel was in 2006, but now the situation is more complicated: Hezbollah is stronger, Israel is weaker, and the entire Middle East is caught up in the winds of change.
(Foreign Policy)

human: Nearly $900,000 is guaranteed to be awarded to the top finishers in this year’s New York City Marathon, and additional prize money could be distributed if athletes break course records.
llm: Nearly $900,000 is up for grabs.
The top three finishers in each division receive cash prizes: first place gets $25,000; second place gets $15,000 and third place gets $10,000.

human: Welcome to a mammoth edition of our Teenagers in The Times feature.
llm: Welcome to a new year of Teenagers in the Times!
I hope you’ve all had an excellent summer.
It was nice for me to take a break from teaching, but I’m excited to get back into it and see what this year brings.

human: The lament is as old as education itself: The students aren’t paying attention.
But today, the problem of flighty or fragmented attention has reached truly catastrophic proportions.

High school and college teachers overwhelmingly report that students’ capacity for sustained, or deep attention has sharply decreased, significantly impeding the forms of study — reading, looking at art, round-table discussions — once deemed central to the liberal arts.
llm: The lament is that the Internet and social media have brought about an end to deep thinking.

human: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese songwriter, singer and guitarist with a gentle voice and an ear for global pop, died on Nov. 19 in Lisbon.
She was 45.
llm: Sara Tavares, a singer whose voice blended soul and jazz with African rhythms, died on Sunday in Lisbon.
She was 45.
The cause was cancer, her husband, Nuno Ferreira, said.

human: Most prescriptions in the United States are handled by one of three companies: CVS Caremark, Express Scripts or Optum Rx.
These pharmacy benefit managers serve as middlemen between the drug companies that make the medications and the insurance plans that pay for your prescriptions.
llm: Most prescriptions in the United States are filled by retail pharmacies.
Pharmacists and pharmacy technicians process an estimated 3 billion prescriptions a year, according to the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.
Most of these prescriptions are covered by health insurance, Medicare or Medicaid.
The rest are paid out-of-pocket by consumers like you and me.

human: “Beyond Utopia,” a documentary on defectors from North Korea, begins by pre-empting the inevitable questions about how it was made.
“The film contains no recreations,” the opening titles explain.
The footage, we are told, was shot by the filmmakers, the subjects and operatives in the underground network that helped those subjects escape.
llm: “Beyond Utopia,” a new exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is more than just another survey of 20th-century design.
Instead, it presents objects that embody the promise of technology, as well as its limits.
The show, which runs through Sept. 23, is organized by Juliet Kinchin and Luke Baker, curators in the museum’s department of architecture and design.
(Read More)

human: The drive from Nashville to New Orleans is 533 miles.
llm: The drive from New Orleans to Natchez, Mississippi, was about two and a half hours.
We decided that we would stop in Baton Rouge for lunch at Don’s Seafood Hut.
It had been recommended by several people we know.
I had read good reviews online as well.

human: Just south of Baghdad, the urban sprawl gives way to glimpses of green, with lush date palm groves bordering the Euphrates River.
But few risk spending much time there.
Not even the Iraqi military or government officials venture without permission.
llm: Just south of Baghdad, the Islamic State is advancing on the Shiite holy city of Najaf.

human: The word sentience has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 15 in “Can A.I. Invent?” by Steve Lohr:
llm: The word sentience means “the ability to feel or perceive.”
I’m pretty sure that a lot of us have heard of this word and we know what it means, but I’m also pretty sure that many of us don’t really care about the meaning.
This is because most people are too busy with their own lives, which makes them unable to see the pain and suffering of others around them.
They may even be aware of the pain and suffering of other living beings, but they just don’t care enough to do anything about it.
This is why I like to use the term “sentient” as opposed to using the word “human.”
The reason for this is that the term sentient includes all conscious beings, not just humans.

human: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE SAINT OF BRIGHT DOORS (Tordotcom, 356 pp., $27.99) is the best book I’ve read this year.
Fetter, the protagonist, is one of several almost-chosen-ones who have shirked or sidestepped their spectacular destinies in favor of haunted and marginal lives in the city of Luriat.
The city has many “bright doors” that seem to open onto nothing.
Fetter’s fascination with them draws him into a web of Luriati intrigue involving his estranged and godlike father, the Perfect and Kind — whom Fetter has been trained since childhood to kill.
llm: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE BEST SCIENCE FICTION AND FANTASY OF 2023 was published by Grimdark Magazine.
You can read it here.
Congratulations, Vajra!

human: Before the war (the First World War, I mean; with so many wars one can lose count), Max Beckmann was painting clean, traditionalist self-portraits and lush pictures of bathers by the sea.
He was a neoconservative with no time for Matisse or Picasso, and certainly no interest in the coming of abstraction.
Then, when the war broke out, the artist volunteered for the medical corps of the Imperial German Army.
He got posted to Flanders, where he witnessed the murderous, meaningless second Battle of Ypres.
He sketched the Belgian landscape, and the doctors and orderlies.
llm: Before the war, he was the most important German artist of his generation.
After the Nazi regime branded him a degenerate, he fled Germany, but never regained his former standing in art history.
Now, in an exhibit at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, Max Beckmann is being rediscovered.

human: Not without reason has modeling been termed the ugly business of being beautiful.
Opaque, barely regulated and often cutthroat, it is seldom viewed as an incubator of big-hearted altruists.

Yet when news came this week that Ivan Bart, the former president of IMG models, died suddenly at age 60 — following what was described as a brief illness — social media lit up with outpourings of praise for a man that Fern Mallis, a seasoned industry consultant and the author of “Fashion Lives: Fashion Icons with Fern Mallis,” called “one of the most delicious human beings you ever want to know.”
llm: Not without reason did the New York Times call this story “the best-kept secret in New York City.”
The 1962 death of Vince Camuto, the founder of Nine West and Enzo Angiolini (who died last year), was officially ruled an accident.
But for decades, rumors have persisted that Camuto’s brother-in-law killed him to take over the business.
When we wrote about it for New York magazine, the family members we spoke with were still divided about what happened that night.
Read the full story here.

human: What do we do with the Oompa-Loompas?
llm: What do we mean by the term “conservative”?
The word itself has become so politically charged that it is almost useless to use, but it’s worth thinking about what we actually mean when we say someone is a conservative.
I think we should understand being a conservative as being a person who believes in and seeks to preserve the traditional ways of living of his society.
This may be thought of as a kind of instinctive attachment to one’s culture.
Conservatives are not necessarily against change, but they tend to distrust radical changes and seek to preserve those things that make up the essence of their culture.

human: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, who had ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in August resigned on Monday, an official said, after facing mounting questions over his officers’ aggressive actions against the news organization.
llm: The police chief of a small town in Kansas who ordered his department to raid the offices of a local newspaper has resigned, according to The Topeka Capital-Journal.

human: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard.
Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.
llm: A team of paleontologists from the University of Alberta have published an article in the journal Cretaceous Research that suggests a new origin story for Tyrannosaurus rex.
The researchers studied the remains of a 66-million year old dinosaur they named Thanatotheristes degrootorum, which translates to “Reaper of Wickedness.”
This fossil is the first known tyrannosaur from the late Cretaceous period, and it’s helping scientists better understand how T. rex evolved.
Host Sarah McConnell speaks with Scott Persons about the discovery.
He’s one of the paleontologists who discovered the fossils and he is now with the University of Alberta.

human: When Mark Basa needed his next dose of Wegovy, he worked his way down a list of 10 CVS stores within a 25-mile radius of his Peekskill, N.Y., home — and struck out at every one.
In the 10 weeks he couldn’t find the drug, he regained the eight pounds he had lost on the medication, and his blood sugar rose.
He felt himself get out of breath more often.
His shirts fit tighter.
llm: When Mark Basa was diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia three years ago, he needed to start treatment immediately.
His doctor prescribed a cancer drug called Iclusig (ponatinib) that had just been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
But Mr. Basa’s health insurer refused to pay for it.
He appealed but lost.
The next step would be to sue his insurance company — a daunting prospect.
So instead, Mr. Basa did something desperate.
He mortgaged his home, taking out a $150,000 loan to cover the cost of the medication.
“It was either get the drugs or die,” said Mr. Basa, 43, who lives in Wantagh, N.

human: “Right now, it’s worth $4 — and a cardboard box.”
llm: “Right now, it’s very fashionable to talk about the 20th century.

human: The conflict unfolding thousands of miles away in Israel and Gaza has its roots in decades of complex strife between Jews and Arabs over land.

llm: The conflict unfolding in Gaza is not about Joe Biden.
It's about a murderous terrorist organization that has repeatedly launched attacks against innocent Israeli civilians and provoked an escalation of hostilities.
Yet some conservative media figures are blaming Biden for his role in negotiating a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.

human: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki and Mariko Tamaki.
(Drawn & Quarterly, $34.95.)

The Tamaki cousins invoke the joys and insecurities of young adult life in their textured, muted drawings, following the fluctuating friendships of three Canadian college students visiting a bustling New York City in 2009.
llm: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki.
(Drawn & Quarterly, $24.95.)
“This is not a graphic novel,” the author writes in her introduction to this collection of short comics.
She’s right: It’s an enigmatic, unclassifiable art object that includes both fiction and nonfiction and ranges in tone from playful to bleak.

Tamaki, a Canadian cartoonist who has won two Eisner awards for her work on “SuperMutant Magic Academy” and “This One Summer,” among others, is known for her keen eye for detail and her ability to capture emotion through subtle gestures and facial expressions.
The pieces here are set in various times and places; they

human: While recovering from Israel’s retaliatory airstrikes, Gaza residents expressed surprise and shock at the brazen attack by Hamas on Israeli soil.
llm: While recovering from wounds sustained during an Israeli attack, Ahmed Abu Ataya told me he was surprised by the ferocity of the Israeli military assault.
“I am a fighter,” said the 25-year-old member of Islamic Jihad’s al-Quds Brigades, “and I have expected that Israel will respond [to rocket attacks], but not in this way.”

human: Good morning.

llm: On the far side of the border, Egyptian security officials also say they are overwhelmed.

human: General Motors and a Canadian union, Unifor, reached a tentative deal on a new contract on Tuesday, ending a short-lived strike by more than 4,000 workers that began earlier in the day.

human: How political should fashion get?

the Oscars of fashion.

human: Wall Street, the White House and the Fed will all be watching Friday’s jobs report for signs of how the labor market is holding up.

llm: Wall Street, the Fed, and you: What to expect from Friday's jobs report

human: As children, Uché Blackstock and her twin sister, Oni, delighted in riffling through their mother, Dale’s, doctor’s bag, both at home and when they visited her at the Brooklyn hospital where she was a kidney specialist.
llm: As children, Uché Blackstock and her mother faced a health care system that failed to treat them as individuals.
When Uché became an oncologist, she found the same problems persisted.
In this memoir, she unravels how doctors have historically viewed black women's bodies in medicine: as hypersexualized, diseased, and undeserving of care.
And she offers a bold vision for how to change the culture of medicine so that it is more effective at providing the highest quality health care to all people.

human: The tech start-up Humane launched a new device, an A.I. pin meant to be worn on our clothing.
Might this be the device that replaces the iPhone?
It’s the question on Silicon Valley’s mind.
The pin allows users to take phone calls, catch up on messages and get answers to questions, all without ever looking at a screen.
llm: The tech start-up Impossible Foods has been making meatless patties that taste like the real thing.
But now it is taking things to the next level, using biotechnology to create new types of plant proteins that will be used in future versions of its burgers.

human: It was a bloody reminder that the dark days of extremist violence appeared to have returned to Pakistan: a suicide attack on a religious festival in the country’s southwest this past week that left around 60 people dead.
llm: It was a simple enough plan: The 12-year-old boy had been asked to bring the car around to the front door.
He did not know what the package taped under his seat was or that it was connected by wire to a detonator that he held lightly in his hand.
All the boy knew was that his older brother had asked him for a favor and that this was a way to make money.
But as the car neared its destination at the entrance of the Marriott Hotel here, the bomb went off, killing the driver, another teenager, along with the little boy.

human: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest U.S. oil companies, this month committed to spending more than $50 billion each to buy smaller companies in deals that would let them produce more oil and natural gas for decades to come.
llm: Exxon Mobil and Shell are among the biggest investors in Canadian oil sands, which could be a source of crude for decades.
But they say that is not why they invested billions of dollars there.

human: The Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza has released a list of 6,747 people it said had been killed in Israel’s relentless bombardment of the Palestinian territory in retaliation for the Hamas-led raid on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people in Israel.
llm: The Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza released the names and ages of 6,747 Palestinians it said were killed in the recent war with Israel.

human: In the last year and a half, New York City has scrambled to try and provide shelter and services to over 150,000 migrants.
“This American Life” takes a look at how that’s going.
llm: In the last few years, a number of American films have been made in Brooklyn.
However, most of these movies were shot on location in other places besides Brooklyn.
The filmmakers often chose to shoot in other cities that are cheaper and easier to work in than New York City.
Brooklyn has also been used as a setting for many television shows, including Girls, Broad City, The Knick, The Blacklist, Blue Bloods, and others.

human: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is as audacious as it is ambitious.
At its core, it concerns an intellectual argument about history and hierarchies of power, but it’s also about the fraught process of making this argument.
It’s a daunting conceit that DuVernay has shaped into an eventful narrative that is, by turns, specific and far-ranging, diagnostic and aspirational.
It is a great big swing about taking a great big swing, and while the film is more persuasive as a drama than the argument it relays, few American movies this year reach so high so boldly.
llm: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is a documentary about racism.
But it’s not the kind you might expect.
Instead of looking at our history of bigotry and hatred, this film examines where that all came from.
And it does so with intelligence and thoughtfulness.
In a way, I suppose one could argue that “Origin” is an anti-racist propaganda piece.
But it doesn’t feel like that.
It feels more like a well-argued essay about why we think the things we do about race.

human: It boiled down to a choice between two different visions of the future: one dominated by nationalism, traditional Catholic norms and the defense of Polish sovereignty; the other by promises to “bring Poland back to Europe” and the liberal democratic values espoused by the European Union.
llm: It boiled down to the fact that people didn't like the direction of their country and voted for change.
The article also points out that the current government has been in power since 2005, which is a long time for any party to stay in power.

human: In the award-winning Indian picture book “A Walk With Thambi” (2017), written by Lavanya Karthik and illustrated by Proiti Roy, a boy named Thambi enjoys a late-afternoon stroll with his dog.
The art shows the dog in the lead and Thambi holding a white stick with a red tip, but the narrative never mentions that Thambi is blind.
Instead, we follow along as the pair listen to street sounds, smell the bazaar, feel the breeze and play with friends.
When they realize it’s sunset and past their curfew, they race home, eyes wide and legs (and stick) akimbo.
Thambi’s mother takes in the muddy duo and finally, humorously, it is revealed that her son is blind.
llm: In the award-winning picture book “Mango, Abuela, and Me,” a young boy discovers that he can communicate with his grandmother even though she doesn’t speak English.
Through art, music and storytelling, they find common ground in their love for each other.
The book also celebrates New York City’s rich multiculturalism.
Here are three more children’s books about language and communication.
Continue reading...

human: Name a stamp.
Any stamp.
llm: Name a stamp.
Any stamp will do.
Now imagine that stamp selling for more than $1 million at auction.
That’s exactly what happened in 2016 when one of the world’s rarest stamps sold for $2 million!

human: Ana Carolina Pejo Henderson and her parents were sure Jonathan Milam Walters would run the other way after spending a couple days in August 2022 wrangling, shearing and vaccinating a few hundred baby lambs on their farm in Artigas, Uruguay, bordering Brazil.
llm: Ana Carolina Pejo is a singer, composer and songwriter, born in 1982 in Buenos Aires.

At the age of six she began to study classical piano and at ten she entered the School of Music of the National University of La Plata, where she studied classical guitar, singing, harmony, counterpoint and fugue with the teacher and composer Juan Maria Solare.

human: As Israel’s offensive pushed Palestinian civilians into ever smaller pockets of land with few supplies, Israel’s military said that Hamas militants had fired rockets from what it called “humanitarian zones” in southern Gaza, citing maps, satellite photos and footage as evidence.
The material and Israel’s account of the attacks could not immediately be verified.
See the latest news.
llm: As Israel’s offensive against Hamas in Gaza entered its fourth week, the international community continued to struggle for a solution to the conflict.
The United States and European Union joined Egypt and others in calling for an immediate ceasefire.
However, Hamas continues to insist that it will not accept any truce unless Israel first lifts its blockade of the Palestinian territory.

human: At China’s top political gathering for women, it was mostly a man who was seen and heard.
llm: At China’s top political meeting of the year, an annual gathering that is a rough equivalent of the United States Congress, there was one conspicuous absence: women.

human: The trucks carrying aid for Gaza stop for exhaustive inspections by Israeli authorities.
They can pass through two border crossings only during limited hours.
Inside the territory, vehicles travel over a landscape of rubble and ruined roads to distribute the aid to desperate, hungry crowds.
llm: The trucks carrying the goods are inspected by the UN.
They are then supposed to be transferred to a warehouse controlled by the Palestinian Authority.
But this process has been slowed down because Israel is not allowing enough trucks into the Strip each day for the aid agencies to keep up with demand.
The number of trucks allowed in was reduced from 123 on December 17th to 60 on December 21st.
By January 14th only 15 trucks were allowed in per day.
This has led to shortages of many basic items such as sugar and flour.

human: As President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine heads to Washington on an urgent mission to rally flagging Western support for his nation, the Russian military on Monday targeted the Ukrainian capital with the most intense salvo of ballistic missiles in months.
llm: As President Volodymyr Zelensky prepares for his first meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday in the White House, Moscow is targeting Ukrainian cities with missile launchers.

human: For month after endless month, nights in Kyiv were punctuated by the wail of air raid sirens and the sound of explosions from missile and drone attacks.
Now, an unusually long lull in nighttime bombardments of the city by Russian forces is allowing residents to do something they have been dreaming of — finally getting some sleep.
llm: For month after month, Ukrainian residents of Kiev had been kept awake at night by the clamor and clatter of armored vehicles rolling through the streets.

But in recent weeks, as the war has moved westward toward the rebel-held cities of Donetsk and Luhansk, those noisy military convoys have been replaced by the rumble and screech of freight trains chugging east with reinforcements for the front lines.
As a result, many Kievans are enjoying uninterrupted slumber for the first time since the conflict began.

human: The mother of a 6-year-old who shot his first-grade teacher in a Virginia classroom was sentenced on Friday to two years in prison after pleading guilty in August to a charge of felony child neglect.
llm: The mother of a 6-year-old who shot and killed his teacher at an Arizona elementary school was sentenced Friday to two years in prison after pleading guilty to endangerment.

human: On the national debate stage, in interviews and at town halls, the message on immigration from every top Republican in the 2024 presidential race has resounded clearly: It is time to shut down the nation’s southern border.
llm: On the national security front, Trump's border-closing threats are an act of aggression against Mexico and a threat to the world economy.
But Trump doesn't care about that; he only cares about his own popularity.

human: Few filmmakers can claim the same heights of whimsy, artistry and storytelling as writer-director Hayao Miyazaki, whose modern-day fables seem to prove that having one’s head in the clouds isn’t a fault, but a virtue — in more ways than one.

From his 1988 breakthrough “My Neighbor Totoro” to his 2001 Oscar-winning animated feature, “Spirited Away,” the sky is one of Miyazaki’s favorite playgrounds, where flight is about more than just elevation; it’s about transcendence.
llm: Few filmmakers can claim to have been as influential and universally adored as Hayao Miyazaki.
The Japanese animation legend has created a number of unforgettable characters in his films, from Ponyo to Kiki.
But it is his most recent creation that may well be his most memorable: Jiro Horikoshi, the main character of his final feature film, The Wind Rises.
Based on a true story, the movie focuses on Jiro, who dreamt of building beautiful planes for the Japanese government.
He was successful in doing so, but was heartbroken when he realized that his creations would be used for war instead of peaceful purposes.

human: Ukrainian forces have stepped up assaults across the Dnipro river near the southern city of Kherson, carrying out raids into Russian-controlled territory on the eastern bank.
The increased activity has prompted speculation among analysts and in Russian military circles that Kyiv might be planning a more ambitious effort to open a new front in the war.
llm: Ukrainian forces have crossed the Dnieper River and are moving toward Donetsk.
This is a very dangerous development.
The US has been pushing the Ukrainians to attack for months, and now they have.
It's not clear whether this will lead to full-scale war again or not.
There are conflicting reports about the intensity of the fighting, and it may be that what we're seeing is just a limited offensive to take some key towns on the other side of the river.
But there's no guarantee that things won't escalate from here.

human: Start by keeping your beans away from light and heat.
llm: Start by keeping your coffee beans in the freezer.

human: This week, the hosts riffed on former Vice President Mike Pence ending his presidential campaign and former President Donald Trump’s sons testifying in the $250 million civil fraud trial in New York.

llm: This week, the late-night talk shows featured an array of A-list celebrities and musical guests.

human: Respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., is a nasty bug.

human: Living alone can be a choice or a pit stop, but one thing’s for sure: The rent is on you.

llm: Living alone can be lonely, and it's expensive.

human: Astronomers have discovered six planets orbiting a bright star in perfect resonance.
The star system, 100 light-years from Earth, was described on Wednesday in a paper published in the journal Nature.
llm: Astronomers have discovered a star with six orbiting planets that are all perfectly aligned, an extremely rare formation.
The discovery was made using data from NASA’s Kepler space telescope.

The research team included astronomers from the University of Toronto and York University in Canada, the University of Washington, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA), Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), and the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.
The star is called HD 131399, which is located about 320 light years from Earth in the constellation Centaurus.
The star has four times the mass of our Sun and is only a few million years old.
The planetary system around it contains three giant planets and three small planets.

human: The Israeli military is preparing to invade the Gaza Strip soon with tens of thousands of soldiers ordered to capture Gaza City and destroy the enclave’s current leadership, according to three senior Israeli military officers who outlined unclassified details about the plan.

The plan also calls for the Israeli army to move into the heart of Gaza City, which is the densely populated center of the tiny strip of land on the eastern Mediterranean coast.

human: Let’s consider a counterfactual.
In the autumn of 2016, with American liberalism reeling from the election of Donald Trump, a shattered Hillary Clinton embraces the effort to pin all the blame on Vladimir Putin.
llm: Let’s consider a few recent examples of this phenomenon, which I’ll call the antidemocratic quest to save democracy from Trump.
Last week, an activist federal judge in Seattle issued a nationwide restraining order barring the enforcement of key provisions of the president’s executive order on immigration.

The ruling was based not on any constitutional or statutory challenge, but rather on the claim that it violated “the Constitution and laws of the United States” — a constitutional phrase that, as far as I can tell, is completely meaningless, since the Constitution contains no general prohibition against the government acting unfairly or unreasonably (and the courts have never recognized such a provision).

human: It is early April, in the evening.

llm: It is early morning on the West Coast.
The sun rises over the Pacific Ocean, and the waves crash against the shore.
In the distance, a large black ship floats in the harbor.
On board, hundreds of immigrants wait anxiously to begin their journey toward a new life.
It is 1923, and this is Ellis Island, gateway to America for millions of immigrants seeking freedom and opportunity.
Among them are two sisters, Anna and Lydia.
Their father has just died, leaving them penniless.
So they have decided to join their mother, who left Russia years ago to find work in New York City.
They will need every bit of courage and determination they possess to survive in an unfamiliar land.

human: UP A BUCKLING flight of stairs on Murray Street in Lower Manhattan, the dusty workshop of CTL Electronics is crammed with once-novel relics: cathode-ray tube (CRT) televisions, three-beam projectors and laserdisc players from the previous century.

Hundreds of outdated monitors are arranged beside money trees and waving maneki neko cats, an installation in a kind of mini-museum run by CTL’s proprietor, Chi-Tien Lui, who has worked as a TV and radio repairman since immigrating from Taiwan in 1961.

At CTL, which he opened in 1968, Lui initially sold closed-circuit TV systems and video equipment, but for the past couple of decades, his business has had a unique focus: repairing video artworks that, since the onset of the digital age, are increasingly likely to malfunction and decay.
llm: UP A BUCKLING ROAD, IN THE MIDDLE OF NOWHERE

human: Mati, the employee at the center of the hushed and absorbing documentary “A Still Small Voice,” reports for duty at an ordinary-looking office.
There are cubicles, roller chairs, a water cooler and flat lighting that the director, Luke Lorentzen, would never dishonor by gussying up with a lamp.

These are the chaplains’ quarters at The Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, and Mati and her colleagues are here to comfort the dying and the families of the dead — to transform this 1,134-bed institution into a sacred space.
They are Olympian empaths and they are exhausted.
llm: Mati, the employee who helps out the family during Passover and other holidays is my favorite character.
He has a very interesting life story and is a really good guy.
I was disappointed that we didn’t get to see more of him in this season.
The show is about religious observance but it’s also about a family dealing with loss and tragedy.
They struggle to cope and find ways to move on.
This is the first time that I watched the show and I plan to watch all the seasons in order.
It’s worth your time.

human: Through the long, busy months of autumn, the calls kept coming in: Mothers losing grip of their children while trying to cross the treacherous waters of the Rio Grande.
Pregnant women getting caught in barbed wire.
Bodies washing up on shore.
llm: Through the long, hot summer of 2014, Texas ambulances rushed toward a crisis.
The wave of immigrants crossing the Rio Grande Valley illegally was so large that it overwhelmed local authorities and led to widespread human suffering.
And one year later, little has changed.

In fact, as the Obama administration announced Monday that it would increase enforcement along the border with Mexico, the migrant surge is expected to continue—and the problems are only likely to get worse.

human: At an emotional evening news conference immediately after he was removed as speaker of the House, Representative Kevin McCarthy gave an inconclusive answer about whether he would remain in Congress.
llm: At an emotional meeting with his Republican colleagues in early December, House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy tried to explain why he was dropping out of the race to succeed John A. Boehner as speaker.

Mr. McCarthy had been expected to win easily and seemed to have everything going for him: a close relationship with Mr. Boehner, a tight bond with Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, and a well-oiled campaign operation that helped him raise $10 million for himself and his party.
But then Mr. McCarthy did something few thought possible when he announced his candidacy months earlier — he lost.

human: There were times, a year ago, in Iceland, on a glacier, in the dark, in temperatures well below freezing, when Issa López thought to herself: “Who wrote this?

López, the showrunner and director of Season 4 of the HBO anthology series “True Detective,” had only herself to blame.
llm: There were times, when watching the first two episodes of Season 3 of “True Detective,” that I couldn’t help but think about how different this show is now.

The series — which returns on Jan. 13 after a three-year absence and stars Mahershala Ali as Wayne Hays, an Arkansas detective investigating the disappearance of two children in the Ozarks in 1980 — has changed its tone, style and pacing.
But it hasn’t lost its soul.

human: In 1996, in a phrase that’s stuck with me, Richard John Neuhaus described the Holocaust as “our only culturally available icon of absolute evil.”
The line appeared in a critical review of Daniel Jonah Goldhagen’s best-selling and furor-starting book, “Hitler’s Willing Executioners,” which was itself an example of Neuhaus’s point in action.

In the post-Cold War landscape, with American power seemingly occupying the stage of history by itself, the memory of Nazi Germany’s genocide came to play a special cultural role in the self-understanding of the liberal West: We might not agree on the highest good, but we knew the highest evil, and arguments about its memory and meaning and implications were absolutely central to politics and culture.
llm: In 1996, in a sermon entitled “The Jews are the Enemy,” Yassin declared: “We have ruled the world before [with] our monetary power, our media, our lobbies, through intimidation and terrorism.
And we will rule the entire world.”
In another sermon, he said: “It is necessary to instill in the souls of Muslims that killing Jews is something great.”

human: Golf is a sport where certain years stand out above others, and 2023 may prove to be one of those years.
It’s a heady list.
llm: Golf is a sport that people love to play and watch.
It’s a game of skill and finesse that combines many aspects of life: nature, competition, camaraderie, and more.
But like any other business, golf needs to make money in order to survive.
And while some may say that it has been struggling as of late, I don’t think that’s necessarily the case.
The truth is that golf needs to be managed well, and it needs to have a strong vision for its future.

human: Tasneem Ismael Ahel’s audio messages typically arrive all at once.
llm: Tasneem Ismael Ahel’s “An Audio Diary of Despair” is a series of 15 audio diaries, each composed of recorded conversations between the artist and people she meets on the streets of her hometown, Tripoli.

The project, which began in September 2017, was motivated by the increasingly frequent power outages that have affected life in the city since the 2011 Libyan civil war, when the country’s electrical grid was severely damaged.
Since then, power cuts have become a daily occurrence, with no end in sight.
In an effort to document this new reality for herself and others, Ahel records her interactions with strangers, asking them about their lives and how they are dealing with the lack of electricity.

human: Few challenges are as complex in Madrid as finding a cat.
Not the animal, but a gato — someone who was born in Madrid, whose parents and grandparents were born in Madrid.

Nobody in Madrid was born here: You’ll seldom be asked where you are from, because the assumption is that you’re from somewhere else, although suspicion — and prejudice — can come up when you have a certain accent or skin color.
llm: Few challenges are more daunting than trying to find a book about the history of Spain, let alone one that is readable and entertaining.
I’ve been searching for just such a book for years.
Finally, I’m happy to report success.
The book is called 1492:
The Year Our World Began by historian Felipe Fernandez-Armesto (Free Press; $30).

human: Shortly after Donald Trump was elected in 2016, I spoke to a friend in Istanbul about my boundless horror, and while I can’t remember the exact words she said in response, they amounted to “Welcome to my world.”
I told her about all the protests breaking out, and she gently warned me not to get my hopes up.
She’d also demonstrated against Turkey’s authoritarian president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, she said, but eventually those protests had died out, and ours would too.
llm: Shortly after Donald Trump’s election as president, a small group of lawyers and activists began meeting in Washington.
They had no money or staff or office space, but they were united by the belief that the new administration would be a threat to civil rights across the country.

They decided their first step was to create a hotline for people who had experienced or witnessed hate crimes and incidents of discrimination: an effort to turn the anger and fear felt by many Americans into action.
They called it the SAFE (South Asian Bar Association of Washington, DC) Hotline.

human: More than 100,000 demonstrators in Paris and cities across France took to the streets on Sunday to show their solidarity with the country’s Jews and to deplore antisemitic acts that have multiplied across the nation since Hamas’s attack on Israel on Oct. 7.

human: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant has made nearly all the rifle cartridges used by the U.S. military since it pulled out of Vietnam.

llm: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant is the largest small arms ammunition plant in the world, producing 1.4 billion rounds annually for the United States military and its allies.

human: When Mary Lou Retton, the decorated Olympic gymnast, accrued medical debt from a lengthy hospital stay, her family did what countless Americans have done before them: turned to crowdfunding to cover the bills.
llm: When Mary Lou Retton was a little girl in Fairmont, West Virginia, her parents couldn’t afford to pay for a gymnastics class.

She got good enough that when she finally enrolled at age 8, she could skip ahead two levels.
By 14, she was good enough to win the American Cup all-around title, and at 16, she won the Olympic gold medal.

From The New York Times: The British Library, one of the world’s largest research institutions, has suffered a major attack from hackers that has locked its internal computers and left its online catalog and other digital services unavailable for more than three weeks.

human: The mechanics of how chess players might cheat increasingly occupies the minds of professional chess players, academics who build models to catch cheating and top chess platforms.
llm: The mechanics of cheating at chess are simple.
A person with a grandmaster-level brain sits down at the board, and then, when it is time to move, he or she sends the opponent a text message: “Rook to King 7.”
The opponent dutifully makes that move, and the game continues.
If the grandmaster has a friend on hand who can keep an eye on the other player’s phone, so much the better.
The grandmaster does not even need to be in the same room.
The person sitting across the board could simply be a pawn.

human: Less than a week after presenting his third collection as Ferragamo’s creative director in Milan this past September, Maximilian Davis was at ease.
The clothes — a luxurious combination of asymmetrical dresses and Italian tailoring — had been well received.
As he spoke, quietly but with confidence, he gestured gently with his hands, like a conductor keeping an unhurried tempo.
Born in Manchester, England, to Trinidadian and Jamaican parents, Davis, 28, the youngest of three children, spent his summers in Trinidad until the age of 13.
A passion for clothing ran in the family: His maternal grandmother taught him to sew when he was 6, his mother was a working model and his father studied fashion design.
llm: Less than a month after the Caribbean’s most popular band released its 2016 soca track “Red Light District,” Machel Montano was already working on new music.

The lyrics tell of a man who is so angry that he could “buss head” — Trini slang meaning to go crazy.
Mr. Montano said it wasn’t inspired by any one person but rather by the “frustrations of everyday life.”

human: As 2023 comes to an end, there is a growing sense of panic in Europe.

But over the course of this year, as the much-hyped Ukrainian counteroffensive stalled, tensions among member states have increased.
llm: As 2023 comes into view, Europeans may begin to realize that something unthinkable is happening.
The European Union, the world’s most successful supranational association of states, may be on its last legs.

human: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.”

Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.”
And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own.
When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing.
Hand is here to chop it down.
llm: As Holly, the eldest sibling and protagonist of the story, Michiel Huisman is perfectly cast.
His face is like a mask, with eyes that seem to be staring into another world, but he also manages to convey all the hurt, fear and pain his character experiences throughout his life.
He's also able to show the more vulnerable side of Holly, especially in scenes with his daughter, Nell (Violet McGraw).

human: For years, a Native American tribe from the picturesque East End of Long Island has fought bitterly for formal state recognition, a designation that was stripped away more than a century ago by court decisions that are now widely considered racist.
llm: For years, a small group of descendants of the Montaukett tribe has fought for recognition by New York State as an Indian nation, to no avail.

human: The U.S. military program that provides leadership and civic values training for students in thousands of high schools across the country will have more oversight thanks to new legislation approved by Congress this week.
