llm: The U.S. military is a force for good in the world, and we need to train our young people to be leaders.

human: In the ancient city of Exeter, three women were hanged for practicing witchcraft in the late 17th century, the last of such executions in England.

Now, merely a short walk from where the hangings occurred, the University of Exeter will offer a postgraduate degree in magic and occult science, which the school says is the first of its kind at a British university.
llm: In the ancient world, divination was used to help determine the best course of action for people and nations alike.
Kings, priests, and prophets all sought the wisdom of oracles, seers, and mediums before making weighty decisions.
In fact, this practice was so widespread that it became one of the primary ways by which God revealed himself to humanity.
The Old Testament records many examples of how God spoke through dreams, visions, and even animals.
However, the New Testament reveals that we no longer need such signs because God has spoken to us clearly through his Son (Hebrews 1:1–2).

human: Ever since Israel withdrew its soldiers and settlers from Gaza in 2005, critics have accused it of blockading and immiserating the territory — turning it, as they say, into an open-air prison.
llm: Ever since Israel withdrew its military from the Gaza Strip in 2005, Palestinians have been digging tunnels underneath the border.
The most recent round of violence began when Israel launched a military operation on July 8 to destroy those tunnels.

human: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Day,” visits a family on April 5 in 2019, 2020 and 2021 — before, during and after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, which shadows the book although the words “Covid” and “pandemic” never appear.
llm: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “The Snow Queen,” is a love story of sorts — not a romance but a deep-seated, long-lasting friendship between two women.
One of them is Liz, the wife of the other, Tyler.
We first meet the couple in 1985, on a winter afternoon in New York City, when Liz goes to visit Tyler at her office.
They haven’t seen each other since college, and their reunion is awkward.
But there’s also something warm about it: The two are happy to see each other again after all these years.
And then the next time we see them, they’re together again, this time in a hospital room, watching over a third woman who has been diagnosed with AIDS.

human: The guys in Bad Dog, a folkie duo from Washington, D.C., weren’t hoping to get rich off the album they recorded this summer.
David Post and Craig Blackwell have been devoted amateurs for decades, and they’re long past dreams of tours and limos.
Mostly they wanted a CD to give away at a house party in December.
llm: The guys in the band were thrilled that someone wanted to write about them, but they were also confused as hell: How did this guy know so much about our music?
And how could he have heard of us?
We didn't even know who we were!

human: The United States-led airstrikes on Thursday and Friday against sites in Yemen controlled by the Houthi militia damaged or destroyed about 90 percent of the targets struck, but the group retained about three-quarters of its ability to fire missiles and drones at ships transiting the Red Sea, two U.S. officials said on Saturday.
llm: The United States-led military intervention in Yemen has not significantly affected the ability of Houthi rebels to conduct offensive operations, according to a new report by IHS Jane’s 360.
Despite coalition airstrikes and ground support for government forces, the Houthis have continued their push south toward the port city of Aden.

The analysis comes just days after an unprecedented raid by the elite Iranian Quds Force on an oil field in Saudi Arabia and amid reports that the Houthis are receiving increasing amounts of military equipment from Tehran.

human: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose direct, emotionally resonant work plumbing the chasms between the knowable and the unknowable won him broad praise and honors late in his career, including the National Book Award when he was 86, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass.

llm: David Ferry, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet whose late-life successes included translations of Horace and Virgil that were widely praised for their lyricism and clarity, died on Sunday at his home in Amherst, Mass.
He was 99.

human: Yes, we know, you get to Carnegie Hall with “practice, practice.”

Breakfast items, coffee and tea, soups, salads, quiches, sandwiches and pastries will be available, and there is a bar.
It will have a street entrance, so a concert ticket is not required.
That’s not the case when it comes to preconcert dining however.
Those with tickets to select performances in the Stern Auditorium can book tables starting at 6 p.m. for a three-course dinner, $139 including unlimited beverages, tax and service.

An initial menu by the executive chef, Derek Prough, working for Constellation Culinary Group, which is running the cafe, includes burrata with vegetables, citrus and beet carpaccio with shrimp, seared branzino, glazed short rib, roasted acorn squash tower, and dessert bites like chocolate lava cakes and apple-spice Bundt cakes.
The cafe area will be open to concertgoers during intermissions.
(Opens Jan. 20, 22)
llm: Yes, we know, you’ve heard it before.
And yes, we know, you probably think that this is just another one of those “too good to be true” offers.
But it really isn’t.
You don’t need a ticket to attend the Weill Café event at Carnegie Hall on February 17th!

All you have to do is show up in person between 6:00pm and 8:00pm at the Zankel Hall Box Office (located on Seventh Avenue between 56th Street and 57th Street) with your valid student ID card and your name will be placed on a waiting list.
If there are seats available, they will let you in on a first-come, first-serve basis.

human: Visits to the International Space Station are valuable, and would-be astronauts and their countries can wait a long time for the opportunity.

The three on the Ax-3 flight are: Alper Gezeravcı, who will be the first Turkish astronaut; Marcus Wandt, a European Space Agency astronaut from Sweden; and Walter Villadei, an Italian Air Force pilot who previously flew to the edge of space on a Virgin Galactic rocket plane.
A launch on Wednesday was postponed to Thursday.
llm: Visits to the space station have become increasingly expensive.
The cost for a seat on a Russian Soyuz rocket has risen from $20 million to $35 million in recent years.

human: You don’t need Halloween to justify reading scary books, any more than you need sand to justify reading a beach novel.

llm: You don’t need to be a child of the 1980s to have read Alvin Schwartz’s “Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark” series.

The three books — “Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark,” “More Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark,” and “Scary Stories 3: More Tales to Chill Your Bones” — were originally published between 1981 and 1991, but they are still terrifying kids today.

human: After drifting steadily away from its source of inspiration — Joel and Ethan Coen’s 1996 neo-noir thriller about the bloody unraveling of a criminal scheme in Minnesota and North Dakota — “Fargo” appears to be creeping back.

The fifth season of Noah Hawley’s anthology series (which debuts tonight at 10 p.m.) is a mess, with a scattershot plot that veers wildly between storylines without ever really finding any sort of coherent narrative thread.

human: Inflation in the eurozone fell to a new two-year low in November, dropping much faster than expected as a result of high interest rates and efforts by European countries to ease prices for energy and food, setting the stage for the European Central Bank to hold interest rates steady at its next meeting.
llm: Inflation in the eurozone fell at its fastest rate for nearly two years last month, official figures show.
The consumer price index fell 0.6% in May compared with a year earlier, Eurostat said, and by 1.2% on a month-on-month basis.
Economists had expected inflation to fall but by less than this.
Falling energy prices were behind much of the drop, Eurostat said, with petrol costs down by 9.8% from a year ago.

human: The year-end holiday travel season is here, and if you’re skipping the airport and hitting the highway for your family gatherings, both Google Maps and Apple’s Maps have apps that can help save you time and money.

Sure, online map navigation has been around for years, but if you haven’t used the apps for the long haul lately, both companies have recently improved their tools for modern road-trip concerns — like finding electric-vehicle charging stations or not getting lost in low-signal country.
Here’s an overview.
llm: The year-end holiday season is one of the busiest times to travel, and this year Google has been working hard to make it easier for you to navigate.
Last week we announced new features on Google Maps for Android to help you get around town.
Today we’re launching a set of features designed specifically with holiday travel in mind.
From real-time flight status updates, to traffic information, to turn-by-turn GPS navigation—Google Maps can be your guide as you head home for the holidays.

human: Theron Truluck has everything he needs, for now, in his 425-square-foot apartment in the Bronx.

llm: Every Tuesday and Thursday, students at the Columbia Journalism School gather in a classroom on the 16th floor of Pulitzer Hall to learn about the news business.

human: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey had a problem — and, prosecutors say, an opportunity.

llm: Senator Robert Menendez has long been known as a master of patronage politics, who has repeatedly used his position as the senior senator from New Jersey to place loyalists into important government jobs.

In fact, he’s one of the few lawmakers in recent history to use his clout with the president to get someone appointed to a Cabinet-level post: Jane Garvey, former head of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), was his choice to run the Department of Transportation when Norman Mineta retired in 2006.

human: In the 17 minutes that Ziwe Fumudoh, known for her witty and acerbic interviewing style, engaged George Santos, the most telling moment was an earnest one.
llm: In the 17 years since the publication of The Lost Book of Mormon, there has been a proliferation of literature devoted to the study of the Book of Mormon.

In the face of such an explosion of interest, it is hard to imagine that in the late 20th century, the most popular book ever written by a Latter-day Saint was a novel about a gay, closeted missionary who returns home early from his mission and then goes back into the closet.
But the fact is that The Lost Book of Mormon became a best seller.
It also created a lot of controversy.
Some saw it as pornographic and others saw it as blasphemous.
But there were many others who found it to be a moving story.
They

human: The year of “The Bear” continues.

human: When scientists take a core sample of fiction from the post-Trump era, they will discover American novelists struggling to unpack the political and social repercussions of his reign.

llm: When scientists take to Twitter, they often end up like Charlie Sheen: a big splash that leaves no lasting impression.
A study published today in Trends in Microbiology tracked the Twitter accounts of 50 microbiologists over a year and found that most of them tweet only once every few days or less, if at all.
The authors argue that the medium has untapped potential for sharing research results, but it may be more difficult than it seems to break through the noise on Twitter.

human: Why is Donald Trump continuing to poll so strongly with voters?

A new Pew survey helps explain why these voters feel this way, and also highlights the deep divide between their views and those of more affluent Americans.

human: In 2014 Jony Ive, then the chief design officer of Apple, came to Paris Fashion Week with his Big New Product, the Apple Watch, to convince the fashion crowd that wearables were the future of fashion.

With this device, Apple has set the standard for what a smartwatch should be.
There are now many competitors who have attempted to imitate the success of the Apple Watch.

llm: Certain kinds of people have always been drawn to the wilds of Alaska.

human: How do you sift through Mexico City’s roughly 57,000 places to eat — more than twice as many as there are in New York City — and choose the most essential dishes?

It’s insane.

The exercise is absurd to begin with,” says Gabriela Cámara, the chef and owner of Contramar and three other restaurants in the Mexican capital, at the outset of the video conversation I’d arranged to do just that: identify the specific meals or bites (or drinks) that best represent the metropolis’s formidable food scene right now.

Nonetheless, Cámara was up for the challenge, as were the four other panelists I’d convened, all of whom live in Mexico City either year-round or part time: Ana Dolores, the chef and owner of Esquina Común restaurant in the Condesa neighborhood; Anais Martinez, who founded the Curious Mexican, a street-food tour company, and recently opened Manada, an all-Mexican cocktail and natural wine bar in Narvarte; the food writer Alonso Ruvalcaba, the author of the guide “24 Horas de Comida en la Ciudad de México” (2018); and Carla Valdivia Nakatani, T Magazine’s art director, who splits her time between Manhattan and Mexico City, where she co-owns a boutique in Roma.

Before we met as a group, I’d asked each participant to nominate around 10 dishes, including a sweet and a drink, from 10 different spots, ranging from fine-dining restaurants to street carts and market stalls.

Then we spent two hours and several subsequent emails and phone calls debating our choices, trying to whittle down the 50-plus nominations to 25 in order to produce a list like those in the ongoing T 25 series devoted to food in Paris and in New York.
llm: How do you choose a place to eat in one of the most vibrant culinary capitals on earth?
You start with Eater’s list of must-eat dishes, from tacos al pastor and molletes to tortas ahogadas.
Here are the top 25 essential things to eat in Mexico City right now, as chosen by our editors, writers, and experts who know the city best.

We asked two experts to tally up the costs.

human: More major advertisers have paused their spending on X, the social media service formerly known as Twitter, as the backlash continued over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on X.

human: Mayor Eric Adams of New York on Thursday ratcheted up his feud with Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, filing suit against 17 transportation companies that he said had carried out a plan by Mr. Abbott to send more than 30,000 migrants to New York City and make the city pay for their care.

human: The House voted on Tuesday to oust Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, from the speakership, an unprecedented development that plunged the chamber into chaos.
llm: The House voted 432-0 to make the 1978 law permanent, and the Senate followed suit a day later with a 99-0 vote.
The measure now heads to President Donald Trump’s desk for his signature.

human: Ohio voters are deciding on a ballot measure that would amend the state’s Constitution to explicitly guarantee the right to abortion.
llm: Ohio voters are deciding Tuesday whether to enshrine the right to an abortion in their state constitution.
The proposed amendment, known as Issue 1, would guarantee a woman’s access to abortion even if Roe v. Wade is overturned by the Supreme Court.
It passed the legislature with bipartisan support.
If approved, it would be the first time that the right to have an abortion was added to a state constitution.

llm: When you’re choosing your new window treatments, you may have considered the fabric and style, but have you thought about how it will hang?
You can choose between different hanging styles, including inside or outside mounts, depending on your needs.

human: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a policy to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda is unlawful, dealing a major blow to a Conservative government that has long described the plan as central to its pledge to stop the arrival of the small boats that cross the English Channel.
llm: Britain’s Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that the U.K. cannot deport asylum seekers from Rwanda who say they face persecution in their home country, a decision that will affect at least 40 people.

human: In the most recent Modern Love essay, “When Your Search History Says What You Can’t,” Kassia Oset shares a cautionary tale of the heart and the browser.
llm: In the most recent issue of New York magazine, Lisa Taddeo writes about a woman who found out that her husband was having an affair through Google.

It's also another reminder to be careful with your online activities.

human: The word ordeal has appeared in 291 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 31 in “I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life” by Erik Vance:
llm: The word ordeal is a noun.

Ordeal means (1) a form of trial by ordeal, (2) a difficult experience that you have to go through in order to achieve something, (3) an examination by torture, (4) a severe test, (5) a trying experience.

and she had been filling out college applications.

human: When is walking in circles a good thing?
When following a trail through villages, forests and fields using open-access paths that begin and end at the same train station.
llm: When is walking not just walking?
When it's a circular stroll, of course.
These journeys begin at point A and end up at the same spot, often after hours on foot.
The British love them.
They’re great for exercise, sightseeing, bonding with friends or family, and for raising money for charities (especially if you get sponsors).
Here are 12 favorite walks within an hour of London by train.
